I own several watches two of them Invictas one a Black Face Professional Diver and the other a model that looks like a Rolex Yacht Master with rose gold face and bezel Both to these are automatics and have been running well for over two years now I recently splurged 2K and purchased a Tag Heuer Aquaracer Calibre 5 automatic that looks almost identical to this Invicta I proudly wear the Tag daily but if I am going some where a little gamey I wear an Invicta looks just as nice to the unknowning and if lost stolen broken or taken in a robbery it is no great loss The only problem with the Invicta is the bracelet isnt 110th as nice as the real McCoy and the power reserve is limited I have to reset and rewind almost daily when waking up if I am wearing one while the Tag will stay running for a day and a half when fully wound Invictas are truly the King of the Throw Away watches 
For the price you cannot beat this automatic watch The picture does not do justice The blue is stunning I have received several compliments whenmi wear this watch Goes well with casual or business wear

This is the second watch of this particular model I bought The first one has been running great for the last two years and I had no hesitation in buying another one for my dad Unfortunately I realized something was wrong with this watch the moment I took it out of the box All Automatic watches need a couple of turns of the winder to get them started The winder on this one offered no resistance what so ever That in itself was a clue to a bigger problem Once the watch gets an initial wind it supposed to be able to wind itself as you move around This watch stopped within 5 minutes I wore it for two days trying to give it enough wind to keep it going but it still stopped 30 minutes after I took it off Since the first watch wasis running flawlessly its safe to assume that this is simply lack of manufacturers quality control Therefore I will be ordering a replacement once my purchase has been refunded

got this last week liked it so much I got 2 more I have about 60 invictas have not had a bad one yet This one looks great and is keeping good time 
A little history first about 5 years ago I bought an Invicta 8926 to get started in the world of automatic watches It lived up to the rave reviews I had read online and I was very pleased with its quality and performance However 5 years is about the shelf life for any automatic watch before an overhaul is necessary it employs a mechanical engine after all This costs anywhere from 150 to 200 and its a procedure just as necessary to keep a Rolex running well as a Seiko or well an Invicta Along with needing routine servicing my old Invicta had become pretty beat up from years of hard usecamping hiking rafting swimming and so onand much as I like the watch I just couldnt justify spending two to three as mucch on repairs as I originally paid for the watch So I decided to get a new Invicta but wanted something a little different than the classic Submariner look and thought Id take a chance on this model Ive had it for a week and am very impressed The scalloped bezel and markings on the bezel insert are derived from the design of Omega dive watches and so offer a variation on the Rolex theme The 9094 is not exactly original but it is unique insofar as it combines features from several classic dive watch styles Also as far as I know the gleaming rather than brushed center links of the bracelet are a feature unique to Invicta dive watches I think its a great touch It also looks like Invicta has made some improvements over the years in terms of design The crown guards are much less clunky than on my 8926 and it sounds like the rotor spins much more easily The latter is just my impression Also the face of the 9094 picks up the light beautifully and like other reviewers I have to say that pictures simply dont do the watch justice Its running very accurately a bit fast perhaps but this is par for the course for mechanical watches and it should settle down in the next couple of months I have one complaint the bezel was pretty stiff out of the box but a couple of drops of TriFlow lubricant placed in the seam between the bezel and the body of the watch loosened it up nicely All in all I highly recommend this watch At 70 and with free shipping its an astonishing deal for a high quality timepiece 
This is my everyday watch It is good looking wellmade for the price and durable thus far Only con is that it seems to gain couple seconds a day therefore at the end of the month it is about minute or two fast  I suppose its better than being slow but this is expected from a nonquartz movement type of watches that use unadjusted automatic movement Its a tradeoff for not having the need to replace the battery every few years If you are like me and like to wear different watches for different occasions automovement watches can be a pain unless you invest in autowinder or two I disagree with some people I think Invicta watches in general I have several Invictas have decent bands that are nicely finished and have sufficient heft to them Compared to comparable Seiko 5 automatic watches Seikos have cheap light weight rough feel to them although the Seiko 5 are also a good choice for a daily beater  their bands tend to give out long before their automovements do These Pro Diver series that ape RolexOmega design are the ones that put Invicta on the map in the watch world Although the style is easy to copy customer service apparently is not as noted by many user here and other watch forums But then if I get several years of troublefree use out them Im happy If you want the legendary service you gonna have to pony up for a real thing Rolex through its authorized dealer

This watch is very nice looking and has a solid feel to it So far its keeping very accurate time It is a bit chunky so if you have overly small wrists it may be a little bit big but I have smaller wrists 675 inches and I can get by wearing it Three negatives it is a hair puller and the edges could be a bit smoother and the clasp is impossible to open for me unless I use something sharp to POP it open I have fingernails and its still difficult to open Overall a great watch for the money and the packaging is beautiful EDIT on a side note do NOT expect good service from Invicta They do not answer emails do a search they are known for ignoring emails Once the sale is made they could care less so be prepared The koolaid drinking Invicta lovers either A had to never deal with them on a service issue or B are so brainwashed they look the other way I sent them over 10 emails over a 2 month period and not ONE reply I am not alone These companies that do not reply to email should just get rid of their email system ShopNbc also has a special email address for Invicta customers and same thing no responses whatsoever I had to email Citizen twice and both times I got a response in less than an hour From now on I will only by from companies who respond to a customer Just a forewarning

Was looking for something to help ease the discomfort of scoliosis in my lower back while I lay in my hospital bed which is for a long time since Im bedridden Someone suggested putting a foam tennis ball under the area of my back where the discomfort occurs So I came across these foam tennis balls I purchased 3    theyre just soft enough but hold their shape well These foam tennis balls solved my discomfort problems associated with my lower back scoliosis perfectly I need this particularly specific item because my physical health problems dictate it My physical issues are due to a neuromuscular diseasedisorder supposedly supported by MDA that is both debilitating and degenerative It involves the progressive loss of coordination and muscle strength leading to motor incapacitation and the inevitable confinement to a wheelchair In my experience MDA is a JOKE I have learned that MDA attempts to make everyone believe that they are out to help people like me but instead exploit us for their own selfish monetary gain During my lifetime of 45 years realistically MDA hasnt done anything for my diseasedisorder  not even a simple treatment

Well I do like Michilin products and they have worked well for me I do use these on my road bike and they seem to work fine I have had one legitimate flat on these splinter on road went through tire and straight into tube and have also cause flats on these by manhandling the presta valve when filling tires in a hurry If you are not so careless these are really good tubes otherwise get the cheaper heavier not by very much to the average guy more sturdy Michilin AirStop tubes 
I bought two of these at Performance bike shop because they were on sale Smooth stems looked nice Both of them came apart at the seam One lasted a few miles from home another lasted little longer but otherwise more walking distance to home I had a patch kit and a pump but no use At least I got refund when took them back to the store I explained the store clerk what had happened and he wasnt even surprised I had different brands of tubes mostly cheap store brand in the past but nothing compare to this I was very surprised because this happened to wellknown name What I learned from this 1 Dont buy anything says ultra light 2 Dont buy anything only because its a wellknown brand name it was probably made by another company I weigh 140lbs so the weight wasnt an issue just in case you are wondering I inflated it 120psi Size of the tire was 700x20c You can avoid pinch flat snake bites by inflating the tire to certain pressure If the tire picks up a broken staple it gets flat but you can patch it When the tube comes apart you cant do anything specially if the spare you happen to have has the same defect Ill never buy it and I dont recommend this to anybody

The Michelin 700c 52mm Presta Valve Inner Tube is a good tire light holds air well no flats yet knock on wood 
These are nice light tubes and theyve held up well so far My only complaint is that they seem to lose air at a fairly quick rate I have to check my tire pressure before every ride even if its only been a day or two since the last ride This may just be a function of the thinner rubber for the ultralight tube but its still annoying 
these are my favorite tubes I prefer a threadless stem so that my pump head doesnt get chewed up and go for the longer ones to fit my 40mm aero wheels Other than that theyre as reliable as any tube and perhaps a little lighter I dunno Its a tube theres only so excited someone can get about a tube 
Even though these are ultralight tubes there have been no problems with flats They do loose some airmaybe 2 PSI overnight but as I always check tire pressure before leaving and generally dont ride for more than 45 hours at a time thats not a problem I prefer the 52mm valve length and can seldom find them at retail without threads aka French valves so its nice to find them here 
After running threaded presta valves and basically ripping apart the pump head I discovered these smooth barrelled presta valves and they are the only tube Ill run now 
I have a Road Race cycle self built These inner tubes last much longer compared to the standard Michelin inner tubes

This is your standard middleoftheroad propane lantern Two mantles adjustable output plastic case plastic base with feet It is nothing spectacular but I give it 5 stars because it does exactly what it is supposed to do with no problems It is as bright as you will ever need One propane canister lasts around 8 hours Mantles last forever if you dont disturb them The case is a must Anyone who has owned a propane lantern without a case is familiar with having to buy replacement globes all the time The mantles can be lit by basically anything with a flame A cigarette lighter does the job fine as does a wad of lit pine needles or a twisted paper towel or a match or whatever Lighting it is no problem whatsoever The hiss is typical The construction is tough 
I purchased this lantern at a local chain retailer about a year ago for our first father and son camp out It worked perfectly then just as it does a year later It produces enough light to illuminate a large campsite but can be turned down to a low glow if desired The case is a nice touch an protects the lantern in transit Ive used it both on the small canisters of fuel from Coleman and on top of one of their propane distribution trees with good success We wouldnt go camping without it 
My wife wanted one of these for camping and as an avid camper I couldnt figure out why We have several camping chairs most of which are MUCH more comfortable than this one but this has one HUGE benefit the tablecup holder Anyone who has used camp chairs before knows that the cup holder on a folding chair tends to be only useful for water bottles and beverages in cansshort bottles Even then they only offer limited stability This chair while not the most comfortable out there has a rigid table surface which is great for setting drinks and food on One thing to note It folds FLAT  it does not collapse vertically like most camp chairs do so take that into consideration as well 
I purchased 2 chairs primarily for use by my husband and me at the back of our tent during craft shows we sell handmade gourd art and woven baskets The chairs are handsome comfortable convenient and very sturdy I was able to place some tools on the side table and work on my craft during the quiet times I highly recommend these chairs for anyone who wants a comfortable chair that has the convenience of a side table with cup hold which incidently has a slot for a coffee cup with a handle 
We needed to replace some camping gear for next summer Amazon had good prices what we needed and they arrived faster than expected Its a lot easier than going from store to store 
Pros Easy to light with long match mantles stay functional for a good while can be BRIIIIIGHT or nice  dim if you just need a small light but dont want to burn a lot of propane We ran our lantern for probably 9 hours over two nights using varied brightnesses dim for most of the time to BRIGHT for about an hour and a half and I still have about half a can of propane With the carrying case it is a heck of a deal 
Picked this one up after that last camping trip where I found I had plenty of propane but all my lanterns run on batteries that were all dead Decided that this was what I need to solve that problem but the store didnt have the auto ignite model in stock Plenty bright and easy to use but I worry that I might break a mantle lighting with matches The only reason for the four stars is because in my opinion you should opt for the same lantern with auto ignite Dont get me wrong this is still a great lamp

Although it says all Coleman 2 and 3 burner stoves it is NOT a great fit on the compact that I own Yes you can kind of jam it into place but it wont be stable and the windbreaks dont fit After looking at it for a while I decided to make some minor modifications I ground off about 18 of each outside foot tab on the griddle and it now fits down inside the frame of the stove as it should little too wide before I also used a nibbler to trim a notch into each windbreak panel so theyll fit around the corners of the griddle and tuck into their retention slots With those mods the griddle works like a charm and my first set of steaks came out great thumbsup from the wife and grandkids As other reviewers have noted the nonstick makes for easy clean up even better with grill spray before cooking After some experimentation I found that about 34 heat on my little stove is the best for meats This equates to about 10000 BTU

Coleman products have been around since the early 1900s and was the name in camping when I was growing up One of the largest outdoor gear companies I have bought and used Coleman gear for many years I was able to use this set several times during a one month stretch this summer and I have to say I am impressed with the set The quality is good and the pouch makes it always easy to locate for meals Although slightly thinner than a home flatware set they are likewise lighter I recommend this set with confidence 
I love camping accessories that save space and time This set does both The quality and portability are really great You can even fit a few extra things in here They did a good job making necessary tweaks to conventional form of spoons and forks in order to get them to roll into the carry case  the forks and spoons are a little flatter at the business end and straighter from the handle to the tip than regular utensils  but this is only so much as is necessary for compactness I bought this set based on reviews  including a video review The video highlighted one drawback that I agreed with  the Velcro fastener on the soft carrycase prevented rolling the set up as tight and compact as was possible It looks like theyve addressed that by adding tiestraps Allinall this is a durable compact and lightweight set good for any style of camping 
Since I overland in a popup truck camper I need everything I bring to be as compact as possible Space is very limited This set was a perfect match for my needs I dont have to worry about the silverware rolling around in a drawer and the case will keep them clean compact and organized The quality is sufficient and certainly a bargain for the price 
For roughly the same price maybe a dollar or two more you can get the Coleman Max Flatware Set instead It has a flap to cover the utensils from falling out the utensils are better made and the case is held closed by velcro instead of the strap I had these first and then returned them when I found the Max Just a much better product 
Coleman means camping but this flatware set is made in China They look nice but have rough edges but are stainless steel The bad part is Meijer sells these sets for 999 regular price The handles are black hard plastic and easy to hold and the forks spoons and knives are full sized and not the dinky ones campers seem to always buy 
Do know that this flatware may not be red once delivered mine was black If that matters to you at all but mine was to match my blue enamel dining set while camping and I am a Glamper so it matters to me I design camping photos for publication The flatware goes back Update June 15 2012 The Seller through Amazon said they will not pay for the return of the black flatware because its Amazons fault it is pictured red So not only did GoCampingCheap charge me 800 to ship it to me but they also made me pay 813 to send it back The flatware only cost 1299 I paid 1600 in shipping charges total on a 1300 purchased Do not purchase from Standard Camping Supplies or GoCampingCheap same companyor you will regret it if the product is delivered wrong or if you dont like the product accordinng to them

I bought the Coleman Tent Fan for a recent camping trip The fan runs on a single Dcell battery and is pretty simple one onoff switch and a flexible rubber fan blade The magnetic mounting plate is a nice and simple solution the plate goes on the outside of the tent wherever you choose to locate it and the fan goes on the inside with the magnets holding it securely in place You have to literally twist the metal plate to remove the fan from its position so it wont easily fall at random The fan output isnt as much as I had hoped for In a 3person tent the Coleman Tent Fan will provide a nice breeze Its strong enough to circulate the air in and around your tent but not strong enough to say blow your hair back in the wind My only other complaint is that the price is a little high for a molded plastic fan Its useful but if you want a fan that will cool you down in hotter temperatures try something larger than this 
OKso this is not some high velocity fan but for the size price and convenience it is great I have used two of these on opposite sides of the tent and they work very nicely You cant expect huge air volume what you can expect is a reasonable breeze and you definately get that Actually the slight hum from the whril of the soft fan blades helps me get to sleep Getting the battery in is a bit difficult and the instructions are not very clear You really need to pay attention to the side tabs and make sure you know which is part of the housing and which is the part that will open up I also am a bit worried about the magnetit is a bit offcenter and may not be affixed well However it has held up so far It is very nice to have an item that actually works uses only a single battery and is not bulky or heavy 
Still have to try this out in the tent this weekend It was a trick getting the D cell battery in this thing but after pulling tugging cussing and busting out a butter knife I finally got it open I slapped the battery in and fired it up She moves some air This can be mounted on a wall with screws attached to a metal surface placed on a metal tent pole or sandwiched between the tent material with the metal base I live in Florida so hopefully this will keep me cool on those hot summer days Hahahaharight It only has one speed and is a little heavy for those wanting a light load

I guess there are people who want to have a fan when they go camping I am not one of them However I am bald and hate that sweaty time after a workout when you just cant seem to cool down With no hair to wick out the sweat it can take some time to look like you didnt just get out of the shower Most locker rooms dont have enough fans either This thing is perfect I keep it in my little locker and pop it out and point it at my head when cooling down The magnet is plenty strong In fact set it on the gratey part of the locker to get if off easier Since I only use the fan for about 15 minutes each time I figure the one fat D battery will last months 
I bought 3 of these fans and in all cases the magnet had unstuck from the fan body rendering them useless on the campsite which was when I opened them for the first time only a visual inspection was done prior Luckily I had some tape to hold them together and was able to improvise The fan worked well and there was no complaints operationally I strongly recommend that you physically check the item and check it before reaching the campsite 
I bought one of these lastsecond for a camping trip It works pretty well Theres just one fan speed the button is good it moves a good amount of air but you cant get too far from it and its relatively quiet The magnet on the bottom is MASSIVELY powerful for such a small lightweight fan I guess Coleman was worried a weaker magnet would cause this unit to fall off of things too easily The metal plate is great for securing the fan to a tent wall and the magnet redily locks onto metal tent poles or whatever Ive used it for probably 150 hours now and have only gone through 2 batteries so its pretty energy efficient My only complaint is that the material the main housing is made out of isnt as durable as it should be especially with that big magnet working on it There are two notches in the plastic base that the batterydoor which also holds the magnet uses to close One clip is broken on mine because the magnet held while the unit came away when I went to pull it off a tent pole Thats why only 3 stars If Coleman made this out of more durable plastic or built a more durable closing mechanism it would be better But hey its cheap for what it is Still worth what I paid for it 
I bought 2 of these fans about 5 years ago At first we only used them at night I was AMAZED that I could run it all night it is COMPLETELY SILENT on a 4 night trip and it was still going strong Ive since bought 2 more as gifts Sometimes I attach them to the canopy over our picnic table or just carry them We use these fans on every trip and I never worry about them falling or breaking or running out of juice I dont know what others are doing with their fans to have such poor performance I keep mine in a coffee can between trips in a hot attic wo battery of course and they work time and and time again with no problems I just pull off the propellers and put the pieces in the can Simple With the magnetic grip you can attach it right to the gear loft and enjoy a great breeze just like having a ceiling fan I love them By the way you might think open blades are a safety issue but they are very gentle and stop the instant they encounter an obstruction Ive stuck my fingers in them many times as have my children and they have been totally harmless The blade stops instantly and it doesnt hurt one bit Its kind of a good party joke The magnet is super strong and holds tight I wish I had these when my kids were in strollers 
I almost didnt buy this fan after reading some of the bad reviews on Amazon but I needed a fan and needed it fast so I thought what the heck Many of the bad reviews point out that the fan is not strong or doesnt blow a lot of wind Well yeah but It runs on 2 D cell batteries and runs for quite a whole on those batteries which is good I found if you wanted air for just one person this fan was excellent at doing that So if youve got 3 or 4 people in your tent you will need 3 or 4 fans and position them over each person The magnet attachment feature works very nicely and holds securely and is also easy to take off when youre done and tearing down camp The small footprint of the thing is nice too Its not too heavy and doesnt take up much space So overall read the reviews on Amazon but realize that for the price and size of this thing it works well and does its job just dont expect huge industrial fan type performance 
This is a review as well as some suggestions for the other reviewers 1 The rainfly does cover the windows if you align it  center it correctly 2 It has excellent vetntilation The cealing does not have a closeable nylon covers inside the tent This is because it is a 3 season tent If you were able to close it to keep dust out you would find that the tent would be wet from condensation inside on the inside So the cealing is mesh to let warm air and moisture excape The rainfly keeps moisture out If the cealing had zipper covering over the meshit would be a 4 season tent useable in winter The tent sets up easy and served us well in our first weekend camoing in it We did not get any real rain so I cant comment on its waterproof effectiveness But it is gaurenteed waterproof I love the headroom and the zippers opperated smoothly without a snag Im happy with it Hope this is helpful 5132008 I used this tent 6 times this year already One night it rained very hard The tent was amazing as not one drop on either of us throught the entire storm I honestly thought that we were going to get wet This tent does what it says Update 2009 Ok it is now 2009 the rainfly ripped last year but Coleman sent me a new replacement at no charge Suggestion you dont need to tighten the 2 side rain fly cords so tight just enough so they are away from the tent You should however tighten the 4 corner rain fly cords snug this help keep the rainflt and tent stable and keep pressure off the 2 side rain fly cords where rips occurred Follow this and you should not tear your rain fly It rained all weekend while camping this weekend 2 nights very hard and not a drop on us third season and the tent still has no issues I really like this tent I would confidently buy another Coleman tent Don

I read the reviews and had concerns but it was the only fan that I could get in time for a campout Overall the fan works It was really hot and this fan circulated the air in my 4man tent While I wasnt in danger of being blown out of the tent it did push the air around and provide a gentle breeze There is very little chance of the fan falling because the magnet that connects the back plate which goes on the outside of the tent and the rest of the fan is strongreally strong So strong that when I pulled the fan off the back plate the back batter cover which the magnet is attached stayed stuck to the back plate The next time I removed the fan I thought I knew better and held on the sides where the battery cover locks on to the fan This time the glue that holds the magnet on the battery cover pulled a part leaving the magnet still attached to the back plate Time to break out the liquid nails glue Ill keep the fan it works but Coleman should redesign the fan The tabs that hold the battery cover to the rest of the fan is really thin and I can see it breaking easily with the magnet that strong

This is a rather adequate small portable fan that will put out some air circulation It is rather liteweight until you put in the monster sized D cell batteries The weight gain is considerable The battery power does not last long either approximately three 3 hours if you are lucky when using this in nonstop mode Have to agree with one of the other reviewers that when you insert the batteries the fan does tend to bulge out and then you have to wrestle with it trying to put the cap back on I too broke the tabs on mine but that was fixed with duct tape If attaching this item to your tent ceiling using the provided magnet it will make the ceiling sag quite a bit especially after inserting the batteries Recommend using this item in a tent where you have some head room and not worry about banging your head on it The fan blade is made of plastic so theoretically you should not have to worry about getting cut Overall an alrite item

Works Good 
Ive been using this stove for 4 continuous months running it exclusively on Regular Unlead Gasoline I buy the lowest grade unleaded gasoline that I can find usually from the local truck stop To ensure that the fuel is free of water or other contaminants I purchased a filter funnel on Amazon The Fuel Funnel is the Mr Funnel AF1CB Fuel Filter at the following link httpswwwamazoncomgpproductB000SOFLHKrefohauidetailpageo06s00ieUTF8psc1 After my purchase of the RUG Regular Unleaded Gas I use the funnel to pour some fuel from the Gas Can into a 2quart clear glass bottle Any water and contaminants stay in the funnel and only the gasoline with additives go into the bottle The water contaminants remaining in the funnel can be emptied into a pail for disposal The filtered gasoline captured in the 2quart container can be again filtered by using the Coleman filtering Funnel for adding fuel to the stove and the remainder poured into empty fuel bottles for later use So after using RUG for a few months Ive not experienced any problems with the additional filtering process The stove lights up fast and allows me to adjust the flame from furnace blast down to a fine simmer with no problems

I have both Coghlans and Colemans dozen egg container and after using both camping my opinion is that Coghlans is better Its because of little things but they stood out to me First the handle of the Coghlans is a little stiffer than Colemans so it doesnt bend as much before the container opens Second using extra large eggs I noticed that eggs rattled around more in the Coleman container than in the Coghlans And finally the Coghlans has one hinge running almost the entire width of the container while the Colemans has 4 narrow plastic straps for hinges These are little differences but my perception is that Coghlans lays flatter opens easier and provides better protection for the eggs

Too small too thin bruising your fingers Crap 
Im being generous giving it 3 stars I think its poorly designed I bought this egg container thinking it would keep uncooked eggs from rattling around in my cooler But I found that even using the largest eggs I could find in the store jumbo there was enough room in each compartment to allow the jumbo eggs to move and rattle around I did not toss the case around or hit lots of bumps on the road as I carried the cooler in my car to see if the uncooked eggs would break  sorry I just didnt feel like tempting fate and cleaning up the mess But Im not confident they would not break since there is so much movement of the eggs inside the case and since there are nibs the eggs bump against In other words the inside of the egg holder is not completely smooth on both sides See my photos above for close up of the inside Then I thought I can still use it to hold hard boiled eggs because I dont have to fear hard boiled eggs cracking and breaking and making a mess But thats not good for me because I want to peel the eggs before putting them in the case which is what I wanted to do so I could have easy to grab and eat hard boiled eggs as an easy snack while driving on a very long road trip With peeled eggs you have to deal with these nibs cutting up your hard boiled eggs As I mentioned above the top of half of the case has these annoying tiny nibs in it cant think of a better word to describe them see my photos for details and the nibs poke and pierce the peeled eggs which allows the introduction of bacteria into the eggs These annoying nibs appear to be there to hold the eggs in place but they dont peeled or not as I mentioned above even jumbo eggs in the shell rattle around loosely in the holder A better design would have been a thin plastic tongue instead of the nibs The plastic tongue could act like tiny spring board holding any egg in place The trick would be to make sure the pressure of the plastic spring would not break a raw egg But once that was done right you could put virtually any egg inside any size peeled or not the tiny smooth spring board would adjust to any size egg and it would not rattle crack or puncture the eggs And the casecontainer can NOT stand up on its own due to the tiny hinges It must lay flat The design has one possible pro the clasps are very basic and seem sturdy The best way to get the case open easily is to pry open the handles separating them from each other This is a good design if you want to make sure the case does not pop open easily on its own or by small children But for someone with a disability or arthritis opening the case would be difficult Bottom line I think overall this case was poorly designed and a waste of money Especially since I now have a plastic container Ill rarely if ever use that I may end up giving away or putting in the recycle bin There are other brands of egg holders but I wont buy another one by mail because the coast of returning is not worth the hassle Amazon is usually good about returns but only if an item is defective and I dont think defective design or poor design qualifies for free returns My loss Ill be more careful next time with items that need to fit properly These are the measurements see photos also Width  75 Length wo handle  575 Length with handle  675 Depth  325 
This is a great egg nest for taking whole hard boiled or raw eggs on the go if you take them camping I would suggest that you seal the eggs  container in a plastic bags first then put them in your cooler We used both the egg carton and the container  put both in a bag tho the carton did absorb the dampness and start to fall apart after the second night I would purchase a second container if I were to take two dozen eggs again  
I just returned from the deep woods and found that this pump was an absolute essential item to the trip It took me less than 2min to fully inflate a full sized mattress When coupled with the coleman 4D pump it took only 6min to fully inflate a king sized bed The two pumps together were a perfect combo If you are inflating more than one bed you can use the battery or car pump to get the beds to a certain point then use the manual pump to finish the job This pump comes with a variety of nozzles for every bed type in the coleman line so you wont have to worry about being without comfort or having to look for other accessories When it was time to deflate and pack up I found that by placing the hose on the other air point I could suck the air from the mattress easily and get it to the point where I could roll it back into the bag without hassle I would highly recommend this pump for all coleman air mattresses

Taken this egg container on 3 trips now Generally we dont take great care when loading items so the eggs had been broken many times in the past But not one egg has broken in this egg container We load it full with eggs and toss it in the cooler or fridge and dont have to worry about any broken eggs at all 
I love this stove I have two 3 burner stoves that I use often There are times however when only a 1 burner stove is needed This is a little jewel that does the task 
The 533 is a newer version of several previous similar versions that earned a reputation for reliability and perfection This stove has some of those characteristics The biggest flaw with the 533 is that it does not have the flame control of the previous Coleman single burner stoves  or at best some do and some dont depending on random luck The 533 models I have used or have seen seem to have two flame adjustments  HIGH FLAME or no flame No matter how carefully you tweek the red flame control lever you either have a flame thrower or the flame goes out For such a heavy and bulky single burner this one flaw makes it no better than the old SEA 123 or old Optimus stoves that roared to boil water fast or burn foods in frying pans The old faithful Coleman single burner stoves like the 508 were understood to be bulkier and a little heavier than some of the competitors but the quite flame and the infinite flame control convinced many backpackers and campers to use Coleman single burner stoves I would highly recommend some of the previous models like the Coleman 508 or others if you can find them but the 533 has few advantages to warrant the purchase 
I have three of these now They work better than a large Coleman stove I recommend getting the square plastic case for them I keep one in the house for emergencies and two in my mini camper to cook on I would not use it for backpacking but they are great for regular camping 
Very hardy stove for cooking onwould not trade or sell it its part of my must have camping items

works every time 
the first time or two its complicated to get going but with the included instructions its easy great for camping may be a little large to have for an all out hike if you get the filter funnel it makes refilling super easy and eliminates any debris sticks or dirt from getting into the tank which is really hard to clean out 
Bought this stove for a motocamping trip and it performed wonderfully I ran it solely on unleaded fuel which was great because I didnt need to carry any special fuel I could just fill it up from my bike The stove comes with a fill funnel and funnel storage bag which was great and if you follow the included directions you should have no issues I do have to say that this stove may be a little large and heavy for those watching pack weight for backpacking But for car or motocamping this thing is a champ It will boil my quart of water in under 5 minutes 
Awesome little stove Perks coffee fast can use my cast iron skillet for cooking compactfits perfect in a folgers plastic coffee can Recently went camping on an island in a national park and this stove by far was the most valuable stove We had a couple other liquid fuel stoves too and they work great when your cooking a big meal but for making coffee heating up water for hot cocoa or washing dishes the little guy is superior Small enough that I have one stashed on the boat and a spare for the wheeler or snowmobile or back packing The btus you get from Coleman fuel compared to propane is like comparing apples to potatoes there is no comparison If you do use gasoline do yourself a favor and use only nonoxy premium If you use regular gas wether premium or not its blended with ethanol which takes its toll on all the components from the generator to the valve seals and rubber on the pump You wont regret buying this stove Use only Coleman fuel and itll last you decades 
Disclaimer I do not own this stove but would buy it in an instant if my older Coleman Exponent or Peak stoves died I once challenged a colleague with an MSR whisperlight stove to a dual boiling a cup of water I had my water boiling before he had his assembled and lit Also I take my Coleman stove on 8 day wilderness paddling trips with 79 people On my last trip with 7 people we consumed only 2 14 liters of fuel My colleagues with the MSR stoves take 5 liters of fuel Also inexperienced users could not operate the MSR but learned to operate the Coleman in 5 minutes It think the extra weight is worth the reliability efficiency speed and ease of use 
I like to have multiple options for cooking in emergencies or camping so I did some research on these stoves After deciding to try one out I picked one of these up lightly used on fleabay for 26 I cant see any reason to overpay for anything As far as some people having problems with these stoves I just cant imagine it This little stove is pretty awesome If you take the time to make sure your stove is properly pressurized it runs like a champ Its very efficient with the fuel use too I got an entire weekend camping trips worth of cooking for my family of 4 out of a single fillup of Coleman fuel That leads me to another important point If you dont want your generator gumming up dont run cheap unleaded gas in this thing Sure you can do it but its like running poor grade fuel in your car You want to spring for the pure clean stuff this stove was meant to run best on If you have the good sense to set the stove up on a flat level surface as you should youll have no trouble using a full sized cast iron skillet on this stove I did it My wife even heated her up some water for her tea in a mil spec canteen cup on this thing I thought she was nuts but it worked and did it very quickly She did use my pot glove to remove her cup for safetys sake My stove seems to have no problem adjusting anywhere from a low simmering flame to a blast furnace I honestly thought it would be a high or low only option but you can finesse the controls to get the output you want Its not featherlight but its not a boat anchor either Id say its worth its weight in your gear It really isnt huge coming in at under 6 inches tall and about 5 12 inches or so across at the base but it has a heft to it being made of steel I guess the best praise I can give this stove is that once she used it my wife didnt give me crap about buying it Thats the official seal of approval in a married mans house Mine was made in August of 03 so these things can apparently last a good while with proper care

I had an ancient Coleman Peak One for backpacking I started bike touring and for some reason thought I should get an MSR stove because of all the hype about how light and wonderful they are Pfffft The Peak One was almost 15 years old and I never had any issues ever of it starting It always worked well fired up regardless of how cold it was Burns efficiently Takes a beating as far as being accidentally dropped and being jostled around in backpacks or panniers The MSR was temperamental It leaked Wasnt as efficient pretty much burned at high no matter what couldnt simmer Then during my trip it died completely I woke up to a 48 degree morning and couldnt make my coffee or breakfast That was it I sold my Peak One so I had to replace it I opted for getting this Coleman to have the flexibility of burning gasoline when I was traveling through remote areas that didnt have white gas Yes its bigger and a tad heavier than an MSR but keep in mind MSR you need to have the fuel bottles and they dont include that in the weight When you consider the fuel bottles into the MSR weight and space it takes the Coleman isnt that much heavier or space hogging Considering its reliability and sturdiness I think its worth every ounce Plus you have the option to simmer Ill never doubt you Coleman unsung hero of cyclers and hikers

PROS This pot is very sturdy paint is high quality strong handle lid has a lip that if installed properly should not fall out Has a nice chrome ring at the top of the pot where the lid fits in a spot that is vulnerable to chip in most enamel pots This smaller model is also good for heating water for tea hot chocolate and dishes I have one for that purpose and the 14 cup model for coffee I prefer percolators over drip coffeemakers I have never had to replace a stove top percolator because it was broken but have owned countless expensive drip coffeemakers Breakable carafes clock to reset takes up counterspace buttons to fuss with filters to replace My simple pot lasts years longer I have one from the 1940s and the cleanup and maintenance is simpler CONS Like a drip there is a learning curve This type of pot does not have a water marker for example But there is a simple instruction sheet in the box Next many of the new percolator pots have strainer baskets that are really flimsy in design including both the Coleman and the GSI brand The real problem is the upright stem it tilts over if you know what I mean If they improved the basket assembly with a heavier grade aluminum or stainless steel I think it would solve the problem I replaced the upright stem and basket in mine with an old sturdy one from a old pot I found at a yard sale For some weird reason most of the manufacturers basket is the same size no matter how big the pot is Most stainless steel kitchen non camp models have a stainless basket Last on models with the glass dome some folks can break them They sell replacements in 2 sizes at Amazoncom for less than a pack of paper filters The good news is that Coleman will mail you a replacement dome for free if you break it email them through their web site seems to be the best way to get this done I am guessing they would also replace the filter TIPS Wet the inside of the basket before you put grounds in to help prevent grounds from going through the holes Use a medium ground blend If you plan to use it on a camp fire soap the outside of the pot and let dry for a minute before placing on the fire to prevent soot stains If you do it every time it will stay looking like new RECOMMENDATION Coleman also sells a 12 cup and a 14 cup in this shape the 14 cup is my favorite and looks identical with the exception of the additional glass dome to monitor the coffee percolating The 12 cup is Stainless Steel and also has a dome Their competitor GSI makes an 8 cup in red or blue

Okay this stove isnt one of those tiny stoves for Ultra Light Backpacking I knew that before I bought it as I lost on of these in one of my many moves That being said I love this stove Its like a refillable rocket you carry in your pack or your car The Good the Bad and the Ugly The Good It boils water faster than just about anything on the market It will also light and burn in just about any conditions you can imagine It also simmer like you wouldnt believe It put out an incredible amount of heat The Bad It takes some work to get lit you have to pump it up and when its cold out you might have to prime it The Ugly For a Backpacking Stove this thing weighs a ton Not only is it heavy but you have to pack in fuel Its also loud Final thoughts This stove is one of my favorite stoves and is never left behind Its heavy its loud and it needs fuel but it will never fail you There is a reason why this stove design has been around so long

I purchased this along with a doubleheight queen Coleman mattress The pump doesnt seem to be the highest quality plastic but I cannot determine longevity based on that subjective observation It took me about 10 minutes to blow up the mattress  which is big  so its good exercise for sure Its not an ultraquiet alternative to an electronic pump as you might think I expect it would work great on smaller mattresses The pump is bigger than I expected it to be but I guess thats to be expected given the larger volume of air it has to move Its bigger than it appears in the photo and mine was red not black However the fact that it inflates on both the down and up strokes is pretty clever Overall I like the pump and for the price I would highly recommend it as a backup for an electronic pump

I bought this to inflate my 4 in 1 Coleman airbeds It works just as advertised and works well It blows air on each movement of the handle up and down hence the dual action label It has a variety of attachments that can be installed to the end of the tube for various types of inflate valves I dont have anything other than the Coleman airbeds so I dont know how well it works for nonColeman products Id be surprised if you couldnt get it to work for anything with a similarlysized diameter valve My pump is red not black like the one pictured No big deal but if youre ordering by the color of it you could be let down

Great cup the color actually matches the Coleman blue color on their coffeepot This is good to know as there are a couple of other brands of these cups but the color is off next to the Coleman pot So buy the same brand cup as your coffee pot if you want the color to match They also sell them as a set of 4 cups separately at Amazon and you can get a set that has dishes and the cups from Coleman too As with all enamelware it is metal and stays hot if you put a hot liquid in it So be careful and learn how to use it without getting burned sip at the edge like a cowboy

After reading numerous reviews and searching YouTube videos I decided to buy this liquid fuel stove It arrived on time and in perfect condition The instructions are included in the box as well as imprinted on the side of the burner To date I have only used Coleman brand fuel This unit works like a dream It will boil a canteen cup of water in about 5 minutes It is relatively lightweight and with a full fuel tank lasts a LONG time between refills I consider myself an sensible prepper and look for quality in my purchases I liked this unit so much I ordered another one Now I have one for my truck EDC and one for home It is very easy to use and makes a welcomed addition to my Trangia alcohol stove and my homemade wood burning hobo stove I have used this stove for about 6 months now on kayaking trips and for camping Not even a hiccup I have Coleman fuel on hand but I like the idea of being able to use unleaded gasoline in a pinch I would recommend this stove to anyone looking for a quality cooking source at a great price

I know in todays world of portable electronics and even portable power its easy to just buy a battery or AC powered pump but let me tell you on many camping trips this thing saved my bacon Its the most powerful hand pump Ive ever used The attachments for connecting to various valve types are permanently fixed to the end of the output tube so you wont lose them and they are right there for quick changing So obviously this thing is great when you are camping and the batteries die or you forget your portable pump but even better this thing will fill your air mattress faster and firmer So leave the electronics at home Another awesome benefit of this pump came when starting campfires Especially if your wood is damp Get your fire started and use one of the fine nozzle attachments to blow a jet stream of air directly on the flamescoals and in no time you will have a blaze going If you are a prepper this is a must have in your bag of tricks I might buy another

The unit can be a little tricky to get lit with several steps of priming and opening the valve in a certain combination Once it is lit you have to constantly adjust it to try to keep it at a certain flame size and you can forget about keeping it at a low flame setting as it will go out That is because the flame vaporizes the gas in the copper hose that runs over it and if the flame is not hot enough it goes out If you open the valve for more gas it increases the flame size initially but then as the hose gets hotter and vaporizes more fuel the flame continues to grow The unit is high quality and durable but it is just outdated technology If you are old fashioned and more comfortable with something you are already familiar with or if you absolutely need to use liquid fuel for some reason then this is a good stove I returned it and got a propane stove that is so much easier to use and maintain a consistent flame size Just turn it on light it and adjust the flame size that simple Plus propane seems to be more readily available than Coleman fuel perhaps that is because liquid fuel stoves are a dying breed

I grew up camping with Coleman white gas stoves and have used them for nearly 50 years The 533 is constructed and operated basically the same as one I have that was made in 1947 I had a 533 for a few years and ran it on unleaded just to see how it would do Like others have found the generator clogged repeatedly Easy to clean but I dont want to have to take something apart in the field when its 30 degrees outside while I really want a cup of coffee It did work great when it was working though  When I was younger I didnt mind the fiddling thats always required to get a gasoline Coleman stove running just part of the camping ritual Id enjoyed my whole life However my experience with the 533 literally left me cold a couple of times I spoke to the owner of a local Coleman repair station who told me that if I wanted reliability I should stick with stoveslanterns painted red or green in other words older models and follow basic maintenance procedures for them In his experience even those running the dualfuel models on Coleman fuel experienced less overall reliability than older models in good condition  While I still enjoy firing up my old gasoline Colemans once in a while I dont recommend any type especially not the 533 to those who desire a hasslefree camp stove Bring a backup cooking option if you can  Coleman makes a great singleburner propane camp stove Model No 2000004125 that Ive been using regularly for several years now It beats the 533 in so many categories that it would take too long to list them in a short review here

I am a big fan of Coleman Camping gear in general and this is one excellent piece of gear to own This lantern will burn on regular gasoline as well as the more expensive Coleman white gas I just use regular gas in it and it works great I have had no problems burning regular gas in it like some other folks have but I do make sure to burn each tank out completely before putting it in storage for any amount of time With the lower quality of gasoline in general this is what causes problems for folks that use regular gasit degrades pretty quickly If you are going to put it in storage with fuel in it use only the Coleman white gasit doesnt go bad the way car fuel does Keep a few extra mantles on hand and you are set for when the power goes out

Coleman camping equipment has been a staple in our family for over 40 years So there was no question what we were going to buy when we decided to purchase new lanterns Our initial thoughts when our new lanterns arrived was that Coleman products had not diminished in quality over all these year Those primary thoughts were confirmed with the first test lighting of the 285700 lanterns Each primed easily each lit with easy each gave off more than sufficient light for reading under the darkest conditions As with every other Coleman product we own we know these lights will give years of service whether we are hunting fishing or need the light in an emergency situation I am particularly happy that no longer will we have to stock propane canisters but have the ability of using either the old standby white gas or if the need arises the lowest grade of unleaded gasoline I am equally impressed that the burning time for the liquid fuel will be around 10 hours set at medium intensity which is considerably greater than one could ever hope for from a propane canister Some may find that needing to pressurize the fuel tank and keeping it pressurized on these lanterns is a hassle but for me it is nothing short of a throwback to the good ol days when as a small lad Dad took me fishing or when the family spent a week camping Who says you cant go back 
I cannot recommend this lantern more strongly than other products in this space The propane lanterns are a postsale continuing revenue stream for the manufacturer to the detriment of a camper looking for convenientlyaccessible fuel In other words those lanterns benefit the manufacturer by continuing sales of propane tanks that are nonrecyclable and nonrefillable This lantern works extremely well Gasoline is a convenient fuel but people have encouraged me to use the white gas Its durable and does not spill fuel if it is knocked over The propane lanterns are frequently knocked over because they stand so tall The center of gravity of this lantern is much lower thanks to the density of the fuel It can be difficult to light without long matches I remedy that by removing the glass globe and top lighting then replacing the globe etc This doesnt work so well in windy conditions however 
This lantern runs of the Coleman camping fuel or unleaded hence dual fuel so hopefully you never run out of fuel for it Fuel seems to last an insanely long amount of time The mantels burn brightly and are easy to change if needed Only downside is it does need a pretty long lighter or match to light 
Works great just like the propane lanterns Saves on propane tanks uses gasoline Bright I highly recomend this lantern to everyone Much brighter than the electric battery lanterns 
I am so glad I saved the 30 bucks and went with this lantern over the more expensive 1000 lumen version I almost think the 1000 lumens would be overkill now Works exactly as it should casts great light and the dual fuel means we can use the Coleman fuel with it which lasts so much longer than propane lanterns which saves us money 
This is a sturdy little lantern that produces a lot of light Produces 861 lumens on high It use 2 coleman mantle 21easily availableUses coleman fuel or gasolineneeds about 2025 pump strokes at the beginning and runs for a long time Does not need frequent pumping in between Heating up the generator prior to lighting up the mantle prevents the flaring of the lantern at startup The lamp gets quite hot so caution is advised A reflectornot included can be used with the lantern to direct the light where you want to and inhibits the light shining into your eyesmakes a slight hissing noise but not a big deal An economical alternative to propane and expensive battery consuming led lanterns Simple yet effective 
My parents had an old Coleman Pump lantern As I remember it had only a single mantle and didnt give off a very brilliant light and being a youngster I always considered it a REAL PAIN to pump up the pressureand that was usually my assigned duty I did it though but when I got older and had my own family I bought a propane lanternthe Coleman NorthStar It was great but now that I am really really old I hate carting around those expensive metal propane bottles that are ALWAYS in the way I dont know why but I was attracted to this Coleman double mantle dual fuel model lantern Quickly adding up the cost of gas these days and comparing that against the cost of the 164 oz propane bottles I decided that pumping wasnt all that difficult after all and I seem to have a lot more time to do that than I used to have as a kid In my area unleaded regular gasoline is about one tenth the cost of an equivalent amount of bottled propane Please dont yell at me and call me cheapIm just more conservative now hate to give up a penny I dont have to The lantern works perfectly the light is very bright and can be adjusted down to gently subtle One tankful of gasoline lasts about two long evenings and the pump even gives me a little exercise Get oneyoull enjoy it and throw away the propane guzzler I also mothballed my propane twoburner stove and went for the Coleman twoburner dual fuel stove WITH A PUMP 
I cant believe how many reviewers complain about the amount of effort it takes to inflate an air mattress with this pump Lets face it Americans are getting soft This pump is optimally designed with a bore of about 3 12 and a stroke of 12 which combine to create about the right amount of air moved per stroke and input of muscular effort It takes about five minutes to air up a twin size 8 thick air mattress The pump is all plastic but is sturdy enough and is a heck of a value for the price One word of advice sit down while pumping contrary to the picture on the box As far as valve adapters the pump comes with four adapters including a boston valve adapter which is an industry standard Blame the other air mattress manufacturers if they have some weird proprietary valve

We have used several hundred of these stoves for over 25 years in our canoe trip ourfitting business here in the Boundary Waters of Ely Minnesota They produce good heat and have a solid base for large pots If given reasonable care they perform well and last a long time If not packed correctly in packs however the four aluminum vanes in the burner area will bend and expose the brass generator tube The next thing that may happen is a fuel leak During a recent forest fire we supplied 30 of these stoves to US Forest Service Hotshot Crews Since these elite firefighters know how to care for equipment not one problem was reported over several weeks of daily use Coleman used to include a lightweight plastic case for packing the stoves but no longer do that A cost cutting mistake in our estimation Overall it is a great product if not treated as a rental

Ok not sure about all the 4  5 star ratings on this product Ive owned both the Coleman model 533 and the model 553 its big brother and neither are impressive They lack fine midrange temperature control versus the Feather 400 model are quite temperamental to coldstarts unless on high and kept on high during the cook The smaller tank on the 533 model means more frequent inmeal pumping of the fuel tank and dont dare DREAM of burning gasoline in the stove regardless what the sales marketing says  because there are NUMEROUS COLEMAN WARNINGS inside the box of what it will do to your stove and its generatorthey REALLY dont want you burning unleaded gasoline in their multifuel stove hey Coleman dont make sure a big deal out of it in the box paperwork if you are going to sell it as an intentional dualfuel stove in the marketing phase ok Overall it is dependable to fire and burn but hey so are a few sticks of wood  and it is about as controllable for a fire as two sticks burning It is what it is cheap You can do better with an Optimus or MSR allfuel stove Why dont you check them out first most of them pack smaller burn better and are built MUCH betterand if you get their multifuels they dont warn you to death not to burn multifuels in it they merely tell you how to properly service it after you have What a concept Coleman products have become a money grabbing poorquality fiasco in modern times I do not recommend the 533 or the 553 stoves as a result of this showing in both products

This is a great little stove I have 2 they make a great accessory to the 2 the burner stoves 425 or 413 While car camping I can make coffee on this 533 while the rest of breakfast cooks on the 2 burner one I have never cooked food with Regular Unleaded Gas RUG but I have used one of these stoves with RUG to melt wax for making candles it seemed to burn just as well as the camp fuel aka white gas  This stove cranks out a lot of heat on high too much really for the smaller pots that will fit on this stove So I use it on medium to low mostly Since this is a single burner it probably isnt to wise to use a big pot and have it tip over I rigged up a home made device from an old barbeque grate to hold larger pots but it is not foldable I wish Coleman would design and make an accessory stand or stove grate for the Sportster II with collapsible legs that the stove could be placed under and a larger pot safely on top Hey Coleman I would be willing to test market such a device This is a great stove not quite as well made as the old 502s but still very good I have had one since 99 and the other since 05 w no problems and use them frequently It is indeed a bit tricky to get this stove to simmer and it doesnt simmer very well but it will simmer Trick is is to get it hot first then turn it down to a simmer the generator tube across burner must be hot to vaporize the liquid If the simmer does start to go out remove the pot turn it back to high for minute or so and then back down to simmer and repalce the pot or pan BTW if using unleaded gas in this or any Coleman Dual Fuel appliance use regular 87 octane or less bc it has less addidtives than premium or super grade gasoline Also buy the gasoline from generic stations that dont offer the additive packages like the name brand stations Youre operating a stove not a car Think about it Coleman fuel aka white gas is basiacly a pure unleaded gasoline naptha with out all the additives designed for automotove gasoline These additives are what plug up the generators so the less additives the better Coleman fuel only has an octane rating of 55 there is no need to use high octane gas Besides do you really want to cook food with fuel that has more toxic chemicals than needed Some reviewers that gave this stove low marks said they used 93 high octane and then complained when it clogged up If the generator does clog it can be user serviced and cleaned or new ones are of course available Its your choice

After having this stove for a while now i decided to rewrite the review to better reflect my experiences with it After initially testing it I gave it 5 stars and updated the review to reflect that I had not experienced any problems with clogging after running over 5 gallons of gasoline through it to date i have never run this on anything other than unleaded gas and it still runs just fine Now if I could give it 10 stars I would This summer on a trip to horn island 7 miles south of pascagoula ms in the Gulf of Mexico my kayak partially sunk and i capsized i floated 6 miles back to shore on the incoming tide tethered to my partially sunken kayak when i washed up i pulled this little guy out of the flooded hatch and set it out to dry this was about 4am by the time the sun came up it lit right up and produced a warm roaring flame its a little rusty now and the pump is a bit stiff but you cant argue with bullet proof reliability like that i will say that it will run much better on 93 octane than it will on 87 and given the minuscule amount of gasoline it uses the cost difference is negligible avoid ethanol if you can it will burn better without it

I am a stove collector as well as a car camper I have many stoves and use them all on occasion I almost always bring the 533 along because it just works well It burns hot with Coleman fuel but I usually dont actually cook on it I boil water on it The simmer function is marginal until it heats up and can sustain low fuel flow and vaporize it effectively As for those of you who chose to use unleaded fuel and clogged your generator tubes please send them to me I will pay the postage As soon as I take them apart soak them in carburator cleaner and flush them clean I will sell them back to you  For those of you who want to backpack this stove is probably a bit heavy Check out an MSR or an antique Svea 123 but be ready for sticker shock 
I needed a one burner stove for car camping and debated on this liquid fuel stove versus the Coleman propane single burner Ended up buying both stoves just to test them out Im very impressed with the Sportster stove and it will be my choice for car camping Convenient to operate warms up quickly with a minimum of flaming runs very hot compared to propane and simmers reasonably well Thee have been reports of problems getting it to simmer but it simmered well for me after some experimentation I think the secret is using reasonably fresh Coleman fuel less than a year old but mainly try approaching the simmer setting from the the OFF direction and not from the full on direction Hard to explain but when you turn the control lever fully to off and quickly back to on it will simmer very stably but will flame out if you approach simmer from the full on direction Bottom line a good price from Amazon and no disappointments with this stove 
I plan on going MotorcycleAirplane camping throughout this summer and purchased this stove about 4 months ago to prepare for the trip Ive tested it multiple times and LOVE it Works on unleaded gas and Coleman fuel as promised refuse to test leaded aviation gas in it though I like this stove so much that I actually stick to the Coleman fuel unless unleaded is all I have as I hear from other reviewers that the unleaded gas isnt good for the stove Doesnt matter as one tank can probably get you through a weekend This thing burns HOT but takes a minute or two to allow the generator to heat up or else it tends to flare up not a big issue IMHO This stove may be heavy for backpackers but for the motorized camper who still needs to worry about size its PERFECT BTW I own the 533 model of this stove from Walmart

I purchased this little Coleman 533 one burner Dual Fuel stove mostly for emergengy use I read a lot of the reviews on it and based on the reviews the Coleman reputation for relibility and longevity and the 533 stoves small size I was sold Back in December 2007 we had an ice storm and lost all power for nine days No power and No heat I like the idea of Dual Fuel but will probably use Coleman fuel most of the time if it is on hand My Chevy truck has a 35 gallon fuel tank so we should always have access to unleaded gas if necessary Now we will be prepared to boil water or make coffe or tea or cook some dinner during the next emergency Highly recommended 
This single burner Coleman has heat output that rivals a space shuttle launch It will run on coleman fuel or unleaded though coleman generally recommends staying away from unleaded to extend generator life Its conveniently sized but is probably too heavy for camping It does keep a cool fount and the width makes it more stable than hikinsized stoves This stove would be 55 if it simmered better After a few years mine stopped wanting to simmer I suspect I let fuel sit in it for a long time and it gummed up the fa tube I suspect I can replace the fa tube which I think is part of the valve assembly in this model 
This little stove is very strong its like a blowtorch when it on high its pretty compact great for 14 person camping or for a family if you only need one burner i was hesitant to get it because it didnt look stable with those little metal supports and i thought it would scratch the bottom of my cookware but i put my pots and pans from home on it with no shacking or rocking back and forth or scratches It heats up water so fast its surprising every time youll never be waiting for your propane stove to slowly heat up water again Also i recommend using the Coleman fuel yes its 810 per gallon but it burns for longer and cleaner than gasoline although all Ive used so far is Gas and i still love it even with the soot its leaves on the stove and pan when your warming it up

I was about to buy one of Colemans battery powered electric pumps for the Coleman queensized airbed Id bought but decided I didnt want to spend the money and the batteries on something that isnt used a whole lot Plus I didnt want to drive my fellow campers crazy with the loud whinning sound of an electric pump This pump is ALL plastic even the handle but it seems pretty sturdy Theres two ports for the hose one on each side of the handle for inflation and deflation The hose has two pins that lock into notches on the ports when you twist the hose on so it wont come off during use The other end of the hose comes with a builtin connector that fits most new Coleman airbeds as well as two tethered adapters for smaller openings The pump is fairly large in capacity Although its only just over a foot tall its about as good as a much larger bicycle pump Still it doesnt take nearly as long as a foot pump to inflate the airbed Deflating does make a bit of a whistle especially at the end but the ability to pull out all the air and get the bed good and flat for rolling is awesome The only thing that could make this pump better is if it came with a bag to put it in to keep it protected and keep everything together Although it is just a cheap pump so no worries If you dont want to get an electric pump for an airbed get this pump Allaround its a good deal

The 533 continues the long line of dependable Sportster not Sporter Amazon stoves This model can use unleaded gas in addition to white gas Coleman fuel because of the included generator same part as a 433 stove but if you use a 433 generator youll only be able to use white gas I prefer white gas and never got good results with 87 octane too much soot This stove is NOT for backpacking unless your name is Varnell a farm boy from Georgia over six feet tall 230 lbs and can tote an M60 on crossbayou treks with no problem Good stove to keep in the truck or in the cabin Dependable fires up with little problem Easy availability of spare parts Not as sexy as a lightweight titanium butanepropane stove nor as weight efficient as a good commercial or homebrew alcohol stove but gets the job done I have made the mistake of buying and selling a number of these over the years and should have stuck with my old green model  it would still be working today

Kind of bulky but a large size is necessary to produce such an efficient manual powered air pump It is very light weight and sure to outlast several air mattresses 
Not only does this work beautifully to pump up an air mattress but it fans a dying campfire too Just aim the biggest nozzle at the glowing coals and start pumping Instant flames It takes me only a minute or so to blow up my twinsized thick air mattress My camping buddys batterypowered pump takes three times as long and requires four D batteries Who wants to worry about dead or weak batteries in the middle of the woods If youre looking for an air pump go with this manual one Its fast easy and doesnt cost a dime to operate Let the foolish campers worry about where to plug in their electric pumps or where to buy batteries when the old ones fail UPDATE April 2012 The pump still works as well as the day I bought it It is a vital piece of camping equipment Roughed Extra nozzles are still attached to the hose They cant get lost

I own this cooler circa 1968 It is bombproof and looks like it survived a tour in Vietnam but we haul this bad boy out each summer because it does the job The cam lock on the lid keeps it from flying free if jarred or jostled this is a very good thing if you take it fishing and have your catch inside Construction is good enough to last near 40 years of use before considering a replacement It really will survive that many seasons of use which is more than you can say for many fragile thermoplastic knockoffs There are few camping or summertime essentials that can be universally adopted but the Coleman steel cooler has to be one Bring it on your next outing and even if you have boring cans of Diet Coke inside people will stop to check it out Fred

Good starter cook kit 
So this is your basic ultra light cook set Ill go over my perceptions as far as pros and cons below then summarize my overall feeling Pros Super light weight great for backpacking  Each piece serves an essential purpose but you could save more weight by ditching the aluminum cup or one of the larger cookware objects  When all set inside one another and clasped together with the handle of the pan as anticipated by the manufacturer there is no jangling or shaking its a nice secure fit  Heats up quickly and cools quickly  The price Much cheaper than other sets on here Cons  Food does stick As other reviews say use sand or gravel to scrub then rinse with water Good as new  Handle can get hot if left on fire or heat source for a long time  Metal cup can get hot when filled with hot liquids Overall I think this is a great set for its purpose I am not cooking gourmet meals when I camp because Im trying to save weight and time and not bring all kinds of food supplies This set allows one to boil water and fry something simultaneously then have a mess plate to throw your eggs in and a cup to drink the coffee you just boiled in It will serve well for making simple meals and eating them while not taking up space or weight in your backpack It is a no frills set up that will be something you can rely on if you are ok with no frills Cant be beaten for the price

It is aluminum and has a tin pan quality to it but this mess kit does the job and it is excellent as far as Aluminum is an excellent conductor of heat and cold and it literally weighs next to nothing It arrives well packaged and includes a plate cup pot with lid and loop and a 7 inch pan good enough for a small fish bird or squirrel The pot is more than adequate for boiling two cups of water which is 16 ounces which Id good for making pasta or hot cereal or rice for two and with the lid on you can probably bake bread in it on a coal oven like you would with a cast iron pot For the price this cant be beat If it last only a seasons worth of camp cooking that is more than my money back but I have heard and seen reviews where people have used this same mess kit for years

This is one of the best TCW3 Super Premium 2Cycle Engine Oils available ashless low smoke means a clean running engine that has more power and longevity Protect your investment with Star brite Super Premium 2Cycle Engine Oil Works with all oil Injection systems or self mix with a quality gasoline If youre using a basic 2 cycle motor oil now just give this a try youll soon see the difference and understand why its worth the extra cost Made in the USA 
Ive used this in an old trail and street dirt bike that they dont even make any more and it mixed great I also had some little bottles that were empty and used them as a measuring cup amount to mix with a gallon of gas So the weed eaters and two stroke garden tiller performed great with it also I havent tried it in a chain saw but I suspect the saw would start easier on this type of mixture than regular 2 stroke mixing oil Conventional oil lets out a lot of smoke if you dont get the mixture exactly right Synthetic oil mixture also prevents the spark plug from getting fouled up

I purchased these to insulate our 40 degree sleeping bags when camping on California cold spring nights With the temps ranging around 49 degrees at night we were not warm enough with just the sleeping bags We used fleece blankets before but they were not staying in place all night but with these sleeping bag liners the fleece is wrapped all around and stays in place Having the soft fleece under and over you when inside a sleeping bag helps immensely The rating on the package said that the liners add 13 degrees of warmth when used with a sleeping bag and I would agree with that claim When we ordered two the random colors we got were a steel gray and a rust orange I wish they let the customer choose the colors but both colors that they sent me were satisfactory I am very happy with the purchase
