Mallet and stakes seem very sturdy and robust Im not sure if the brush and pan will be much use as they are pretty small Im also not sure how folks reported they bent the stake puller as I tried to mess it up and couldnt Basically the whole kit is a little cheaper than just buying four stakes and a mallet so it is a pretty good bargain 
Unlike my 2mantle lantern this little lamp can be turned down very low and the control even has detents so that you can tell which setting youre selecting On full brightness its about half as bright as a 2mantle lantern  which is quite adequate for many purposes But its gas consumption is also half that of a 2mantle lantern so you can really stretch the fuel when you turn the light down low According to the label a tank lasts 12 hours at full output or 18 at reduced output I was without power for 10 days after Hurricane Sandy when there were no gas bottles to be found anywhere I only had a few so I was very happy to have this little gas miser I had no problem installing the mantle but like another reviewer I reduced the rating one star for workmanship The lamp does not sit quite straight on the gas bottle and the globe is not centered within the wire guard An additional concern is that this lantern hangs from a rather short chain rather than a hardened wire hoop like the larger lanterns I reduced the rating an additional star because the chain gets so hot that you cant touch it without receiving a severe burn Moreover anything it hangs from might be singed or ignited so youll need to operate it in a support ring on a flat surface While I appreciate the effort to make this lantern as portable as possible the conventional wire hoop is an indispensable safety feature 
We really like our little light We replaced a 2 mantle lantern with this one This thing doenst put out nearly the amount of light that our 2 burner did but its still plenty It takes up WAY less room in our camping tote which is a good thing for us since we camp in a Jeep and have to keep things small The mantle was pretty easy to put on I just made sure to do it at the house before we left The mantles are hard to come by I havent seen them anywhere Im glad we ordered some ahead of time I was kind of worried that the carrying chain would get hot but it didnt I took off one star because its just not as bright as the bigger lights We may buy another one to have on either side of the camp It uses very little fuel over a period of time Good light 
This is a nice lantern I agree with other reviewers that the threads could have been made stronger but then it is an inexpensive unit Evidently to keep the weight down and for corrosion resistance the base is made of a zinc alloy That is all good but a castin steel thread or a helicoil could have been employed in the design The instructions were very sketchy It says to install the mantle Uhh this is my first lantern my first mantle By the way what is a mantle Anyway I just slipped it over the post and hoped for the best There were no strings to tie And the product description says that to light you must use matches a lighter However the unit I got has a piezoelectric starter which so far works nicely And of course since I did not know how to install the mantle I thought the electrodes for the starter which were not supposed to exist might have been a place to tieoff the strings that appear on the photos but did not exist on the product It was hard to get the mantle to light the first time and I even blew the lid off That was scary but cool But subsequently the starter works very nicely I ordered a lighter for it but I wont be using it The lantern is small and light weight It will only get intermittent use from me so it may last a long time Dont look at the flame for very long Youll be seeing the sun for quite a while Addendum In case you are wondering which replacement mantles to get these are the originalsnbspa datahookproductlinklinked classalinknormal hrefColemanCompany2Pk51LantMantle51A104LanternAccessoriesdpB000PB7JBMrefcmcrarpdrvwtxtieUTF8Coleman Company 2Pk 51 Lant Mantle 51A104 Lantern Accessoriesanbsp no strings to tieoff

love this item for a quick and easy pump inflate for a camping trip so glad we purchased it before our latest trip 
After recently purchasing a camper that had a stove but no oven my family was faced with either giving up some of our favorite breakfast foods like biscuits and cinnamon rolls and easy bake desserts like brownies or buy a stand alone oven that would work on a camp stove like this Coleman While we have only used it on one trip so far it performed well for what it is and can be improved upon with a little knowledge and preplanning First of all several reviewers have mentioned how this oven cooks at a higher temp than the simple temperature guage reads This seems to be true for mine as well I am guessing based on cook time that at a reading of 350 degrees the oven was closer to 400 or a bit higher Even checking the rolls a few minutes earlier than the earliest cook time at 400 degrees the bottoms got a bit burned at 350 degrees Try cooking at a lower temperature and taking your time to avoid brown or crusty rollbuscuitcornbread bottoms Unless your guage is closer to true temps than mine you would be better off to assume the reading is 2550 degress cool and cook accordingly Another tip is to move foods that will fit to one of the top two racks when cooking This can also help the top side of your baked goods heat up a little better and more evenly with the bottom of the pan Finally use as thick and heavy a pan as will fit andor locate a small round or small rectangular pizza stone that will fit inside on the bottom of the oven to help regulate the heat intensity and hold temperature better when opening the door to check progress With just a little effort this Coleman Camp Oven can work pretty well despite its light weight and construction Also folds down flat for easy transporting

I left a shorter review of this cooler earlier but after further use wanted to return to leave a more comprehensive review INTRODUCTION I purchased this cooler on the recommendation of a friend who had several at a tailgate party I attended After searching around for the best price I settled on purchasing the green colored cooler which was the cheapest at the time from Amazon As a prime eligible purchase it arrived two days later in perfect condition Absolutely no dings scratches or dents like other reviews mention It was perfectly packaged in factory boxes APPEARANCE The cooler is plastic encased in steel The colored portion you see is steel whereas the white portion is plastic Some people seem to believe this cooler is all steel It is not It is steel belted as the description clearly states The latch is metal and plastic The handles are also metal but with plastic grips The coolers appearance is stylish Also there is NO bottle opener on this version of the cooler Some reviews allude to the presence of a bottle opener on the outside of the cooler There is certainly not one on the version I ordered FUNCTIONALITY AND USE Hands down this is the best cooler I have ever owned I take a lot of road trips and travel a lot for work and used to carry along an old generic plastic cooler with me to keep snacks water and soda This cooler has replaced my old beat up travel buddy It fits nicely in the back of my Ford Escape and has more then enough storage space for meats cheese bread yogurt fruit beer and ice I can stock it with enough food for a 35 day trip easily The cooler keeps ice for about two to three days outside of extreme temperatures Two or three two liter bottles of ice are enough to keep everything cold for at least 2 says If necessary the ice can be supplemented with a bag of two from the motel to get you through the last day or two of your trip I do not use the chemical ice packs except one small one see below but they might last a little longer Now just one thing to consider before you purchase this item The cooler can get heavy especially when fully loaded Of course it depends on what you put in the cooler but I have loaded mine up to what was probably more then fifty pounds That can be a lot of weight to carry especially longer distances Unless you are a large burly man dont plan on carry this cooler fully loaded around all day long The plastic grips do a good job of stopping the handles from cutting into your hands when carrying and it is on the heavy side To get around this limitation I keep a small cold pack in the cooler and a small insulated bag I got as a freebie at a convention Whenever I need to take something from the car to a different location and do not want to lug the entire cooler I just place what I need in the insulated bag with the cold pack TIPS 1 Dont waste your money buying bagged ice at convenience stores Fill recycled two liter bottles 34 way full of water and freeze them Use these bottles as ice packs It will not only save you the mess of melted ice but also a few dollars because you wont have to buy ice 2 Make sure to chill everything that will go in the cooler at least overnight This will help extend the life of the ice in the cooler 3 It is useful to keep something like a bottle opener or cork screw in your cooler Even a small folding knife can be a lifesaver when you need to cut open a package or some food CONCLUSION This cooler is well worth the money Yes you can find cheaper alternatives in stores and online But the value of this cooler cannot be surpassed You may save a few dollars by buying a generic plastic cooler but those savings will quickly be lost with all your ice purchases and loss of food due to heat 
We had the best biscuits and cinnamon rolls ever during our last camping trip Who wouldve thought that this little square box would work so well Set the camp stove temp to medium to preheat and watch the temp gauge on the door Dont leave it once you put the food in the oven to monitor the temp But by adjusting your flame you can increase or decrease the oven temperature I also used the disposable mini casserole pans from the grocery store It made clean up so easy afterwards The toaster oven tray sets seem to run just a little big for this camp oven 
Will this bake bread yes Will it come together with a working door and fully attached handle no The oven itself is a great little addon for those who do not want to bake in a Dutch oven I have made bread and muffins in mine and I can think of many other uses for future camping trips But the handle was only soldered in on one side and broke one the first use and the door knob is just cheap So if you are looking for a metal oven that breaks down here it is If you are looking for a great piece of camping hardware for the long term this isnt it But then again at 40 its an ok deal 
So far I have made biscuits in this oven and they turned out perfectly One thing to keep in mind is that when you open the door to place something in it the door thermo suddenly reads much cooler than the inside temp actually is Just place the food item in there and cook for the correct amount of time

Bought this to inflate pools beach balls etc Does an excellent job and does it very quickly Comes with the various adapters for nozzles that are likely to be found on those type of toys Also comes with clear instructions I inflated a large toddlers pool and did it in under three minutes In use the noise is not much more than a hair dryer and outside the noise is less noticable The exhaust valve on the pump becomes the reverse port to deflate the toy The pump weighs only a few ounces and is easily connected to any pool or inflatable toy I was concerned that the price was so low but the Coleman name convinced me I am very happy with the purchase 
I write this as a eulogy to my Coleman air pump I paid 20 for it 5 years ago and its the best 20 I ever spent I have sent this pump to hell and back  several times Were campers and boaters and my kids are outdoor freaks  air mattresses inflatable pools bounce houses intertubes water islands backyard and on and on  too much I used to lug around an air compressor with me everywhere and was surprised to find this thing pumps out substantially more air than a 120psi high pressure air compressor Like the other reviewer said  its just a fan  not made for high pressure but it IS made for high velocity This pump has ran like a champ since the day we bought it We take it on the boat in the motorhome and it has a permanent spot in my garage next to the compressor I use it for everything It gets tossed into storage bins left outside fallen on the ground a few times rolls around in the back of the truck take it down to the sand etc Its been beat up about as much as anything could get beat Mine has an 18 extender hose on it which looks like its been removed from the product since I bought mine  too bad I always use the hose and I think I would be bummed out if I lost it After 5 years I can hear the motor finally conking out Its not dead yet but I cant risk being stranded without it  its way too valuable Because we do have so many inflatables and some of them are really really big Im going to step it up and try out the Kwik Tek High Pressure this time around Ill keep the Coleman until it dies completely but Im curious to see if the Kwik Tek can fill the Coleman shoes I feel an obligation to offer my support for this little champ It did really really great and if my Kwik Tek disappoints Im back to the Coleman for sure If youre looking for a GREAT pump and cant decide what to get I highly recommend the Coleman  for the price durability and function its a winner

I bought this oven to compliment my recent purchase of a StoveTec rocket stove The idea was to be able to bake bread or rolls in a camping or emergency situation This worked out better than I could have imagined One full size loaf of bread baked to golden brown perfection in about 25 minutes 
The Coleman ovens have been around since at least 1960 from what I can find The fact that the design exists today nearly unchanged is a tribute to the product itself Unlike the early steel models Newer models are made of lighterweight aluminum The Coleman ovens are designed to sit on top of the traditional box type Coleman two or three burner stoves with the heat of a single burner providing the heat They work best in windless environments with the temperature over 50 degrees In windy environments andor temperatures approaching 30 degrees F or less The oven is more finicky with the temperature more difficult to control and maintain In these challenging conditions the baking can have hot spots where four biscuits cooking at the same time might have two perfect and two burned Getting the tops of food to brown without burning the bottom takes a lot of experience and is something I have not mastered So the oven is not perfect but that is all part of the camping cooking experience  to try to achieve perfection in more challenging environments You can enhance the performance of the oven by draping a couple sheets of aluminum foil around the oven when using it The Coleman oven does expand the camp menu significantly Now you can have pizza at camp which is a novelty Instead of griddle cakes you can have muffins Instead of fried eggs you can have quiche If you have picky eaters or new campers the Coleman oven can bring some familiarity and comfort by offering foods typically enjoyed at home The Coleman oven is a fun device that adds a bit of a thrill for both the cook and the outdoor diners Imagine having hot pizza or hot brownies right at your favorite lakeside campground in the middle of nowhere

This thing is AWESOME Looks cool works great THIS OVEN IS NOT FOR USE OVER A CAMPFIRE When used on a propane camp stove It will NOT twist and deform like some reviewers claim For those using the oven in a very COLD or WINDY environment You WILL have more trouble keeping the heat high COMMON SENSE MUST PREVAIL Some reviewers claim that it wont reach baking temps without wrapping the oven in aluminum foil That is a dead giveaway that they are baking in a windy or cold area If you have that ELUSIVE characteristic called COMMON SENSE You will absolutely love this camp oven

Valve has stops for propane levels with the first 2 stops doing nothingno propane released  Then the next two stops fire up but are low flame on the first stop then too high flame on the next stop too hot So true adjust ability is absent thus the trouble with valve stops versus a free moving valve with no stops  TDC

I have seen these ovens on store shelves most of my life I was certain that a little aluminum box could not function as an oven But recently we were embarking on a 10day camping trip and I was going to need to bake while we were there I am pretty adept at baking with coals from a campfire or a charcoal fire but on the trip in question there was a burn ban in effect What to do I got on Amazon and read reviews about the Coleman Camp Oven and decided that if my original opinion was correct Coleman wouldnt still be making this little gem I purchased the oven and it arrived when promised We took it to the campground and were totally amazed at how beautifully it worked We baked brownies biscuits potatoes cornbread and even glutenfree hamburger buns and rolls Everything was wonderful The oven was easy to set up and use But it is not like baking at home in your regular oven Tips you should know  Only use the oven on a camp stove Try to get your stove as level as possible  Start warming it up with a low flame and increase the stove flame as the oven begins to preheat  Plan to use small bakeware Coleman suggests 8x8 pans Here are some products that we found worked well nbspa datahookproductlinklinked classalinknormal hrefNordicWareToasterOvenBakingSheetdpB00004RFS9refcmcrarpdrvwtxtieUTF8Nordic Ware Toaster Oven Baking Sheeta  Ekco mini muffin pan for 12 muffins nbspa datahookproductlinklinked classalinknormal hrefFoxRunSetofFourEnglishMuffinRingsdpB0000CFME7refcmcrarpdrvwtxtieUTF8Fox Run Set of Four English Muffin Ringsanbspfor the burger buns on the baking sheet nbspa datahookproductlinklinked classalinknormal hrefMSRBlackliteFryPandpB000FBYNIErefcmcrarpdrvwtxtieUTF8MSR Blacklite Fry Pana  8x8 foil pan  After your food is in the oven you really need to watch the temperature gauge from time to time The longer it bakes the more likely you will need to adjust the stove flame to regulate the temperature inside the oven This is NOT setitandforgetit baking  We found that timing was pretty close to baking at home as long as the temperature was constant  Try not to peek too often Peeking lowers the internal temperature Look when you need to  thats all  Clean up spills outside and inside as soon as the oven cools Dont let gunk bake on during the next use The oven folds up quickly when it is time to pack up We keep it in its original box and it is ready to go I still love the thrill of accomplishment of baking using a campfire but this little oven is a great addition for those times when a fire is not convenient May we all have many years of excellent campground baking Happy Camping Happy Baking Happy Eating

pay attention The thermodynamic properties of aluminized steel are beyond the scope of this review but suffice it to say that one should not initially turn the burner on full blast or the box will not heat evenly and could warp Likewise one should not place this directly over a camp fire For campfire cooking get a dutch oven You can make great things in those too For this oven I keep the burner low This is a great cooler It holds a ton is strong and takes banging around It is good for dragging stuff for a family outing to the park or for car camping Not a backpackable cooler mind you but this is the heirloom cooler you will want for decades We use ours as a minifridge in a lake cabin and it keeps stuff cold with occasional changes of ice or cooler blocks 
When Coleman designed this cooler they left off a way to stop the lid from opening past 90ish degrees This results in the lid opening about 180 degrees which stresses the hinges and breaks the outer stainless layer away from the inner insulation I have been through two lids and now the body of the cooler is breaking away the same way Yes it does have a 100 year warranty but I bought expecting the same build quality as my grandfathers that is 60 years old There is just no comparison Coleman also says it will keep ice for 3 days at 100 degrees This couldnt be further from the truth It will not hold ice for 24 hours at 85 degrees Bottom line Buy a good Igloo marine cooler and use the extra 70 to fill it with your beverage of choice

good 
This is a nice set but the quality is mixed First the 4 big tent stakes are what I wanted the least when I bought the kit but they turned out to be the best thing about it I was camping in the Rockies recently and had to set up my tent on very hard ground and these were the best stakes for the job I couldnt even get the little metal stakes that came with my tent to go into the ground and the larger yellow plastic stakes got all bent up I wound up going out and buying a dozen more of these big stakes which are basically nails with green hooks on top The green hooks are kinda flimsy unfortunately The mallet is nice for pounding in the small metal or plastic stakes but pounding the big metal stakes into hard ground did leave some scars in the mallets rubber head Itd be nice if one side of it had a metal cap or something The stakepuller is basically too weak to pull out any stakes that you cant just pull by hand although its nice to use so you dont strain your hands Its completely worthless for pulling stakes from hard ground and will just bend until its wrecked Im going to buy a small crowbar instead The dustpan is pretty flimsy Mine immediately cracked along its edge if I didnt receive it that way Its also pretty difficult to put back in the bag All in all its a cheap set but youre basically just getting a decent mallet 4 good stakes and an occasionallyconvenient stake puller Oh and the bag is pretty good 
Worked well and the tools that came with it are perfect I just wish it came with more than 4 stakes since I needed 8 for my tent and rainfly

PROS Very sturdy under the light pan that we use while camping It sits pretty flat on the propane tank so liquid doesnt collect on one side of the pan It works quickly to heat our cooking gear Pretty small easy to pack and carry CONS The gas knob is very sensitive On its lowest couple of settings the little amount of gas let out if any wont light with a lighter On medium settings it goes from no flame to a pretty hot flame making it hard to cook properly It ends up being more of an onoff switch than an adjustable knob Overall its a good stove for those who dont feel the need to eat gourmet food while camping

I was really hoping to give this a good review because I love Coleman but the stove is small heavy not easy to compact carry and it leaks like crazy Even at absolute off the stove will still leak a small but steady flame if there is no wind I blame it on the design of the knob being so easily exposed and fairly cheaply made The rest of the stove could hold a damn picnic table but the control knob is super cheap plastic in the wrong place I have only taken this camping once did not abuse it and it was brand new About the 3rd time I used it I noticed the gas leak This seems like a great idea as a backup stayathome just in case type stove but it is not light enough for hiking and it leaks so bad that you wouldnt think to leave on your propane tank ever That said it is a good working stove that can make a single propane tank last quite a while 
Thick metal construction and ample size can handle the heaviest pots Only downside is the variable gas valve has only three useful levels without the option to choose anything in between as it stepsjumps as it turns There is no good low setting to keep things just warm 
I bought this lamp based on reviews of others There were other models that I looked at but I went with this one because many people said the light was bright and that is what I wanted When I received it and I charged it for one day I tested it out and the high setting and low setting seem to put out the same amount of light and in my opinion it wasnt that bright I may have been expecting something more but it is bright enough for you to see and to do things without having to use one hand to hold a flashlight I havent tested out how long it truly last and it is a bit heavy because of the battery 
Ive been using this stove for about a year now Its a heavy wellmade burner best suited for car camping where size and weight are not big concerns A major advantage of this burner is the low cost and wide availability of the 16 oz propane canisters that power it You get far more bang for your fuel buck with this stove as compared to stoves using the smaller isobutane canisters At my local big box store a 16 oz propane canister costs about 250 whereas an 8 oz isobutane fuel canister costs 5 Twice the fuel for half the cost is never a bad thing Propane canisters also last a long time and are widely available Lighting this burner is easy Simply turn the knob to release the gas and provide a spark manually and youre cooking The simplicity of this burner also has advantages in reliability As for cooking performance this stove excels at boiling water and tasks that require a high flame The major flaw is that this stove doesnt have a setting that I would describe as truly low If youre cooking foods that are prone to sticking or burning on thin camping cookware you will find that this stove burns too hot even on the lowest setting A couple times Ive made pancakes on camping trips and I had to hold my pan above the stove to avoid burning even on low It hasnt been a problem on most foods but the lack of a very low setting can be troublesome Id recommend checking out the Stansport burner here on Amazon or the Ozark Trail brand burner sold at Walmart I believe both will do a better job cooking at low temp Other than that this is an inexpensive reliable and wellmade burner that works great If simmering or lowflame performance is a concern for you I would pass on this stove

just used it on a week long camping trip loved it

I have had dozens of different camping lanterns from liquid gas to propane to battery powered but never one like this rechargeable lantern The night light function is great when you need a little light around the room or tent but dont want to destroy your night vision The two level light selection is also great when you are nursing the battery life for all it is worth out where there is no electricity to hook up to I bought one tried it for about six months and came back for a second one based on my experience with the first If you live where power outages are fairly common camp in the wilderness or live off the power grid this is the lantern to beat all lanterns My power generator ran out of fuel during a big dinner celebration and we grabbed our lanterns a few candles and the party continued Buy a couple of these for your RV or camping trailer you wont regret it 
I love that this lantern can be plugged into a wall socket and if the power goes off it will come on provided you have the switch to the high or low position You can test it to make sure it is working by plugging it in turning the switch to the high position and then unplugging it when plugged in it should be turned off and when unplugged it should turn on automotically the advantages of this turning on automatically are manymostly though if it is completely dark and the outage was unexpected you automatically have a light for safety to move about to look for other emergency supplies This is a very heavy lantern so i cant imagine taking it backpacking Although I could see the great benefit to having it camping If the battery dies you can recarge it with the included car charger stored in base of unit I am very satisfied with this purchase and wouldnt hesitate to buy it again

Bought this as prime and the delivery was very fast I was surprised when I opened the box and found it was not in new condition thats why didnt give it five stars It obviously has been used before from the burn marks on the orifice and the pot rests Seems to work so I guess Ill keep it Some folks complain about not having a propane tank included Read the description It clearly states you need to buy the propane separately 
I love this stove Ive had mine four years now and it still works like new I recently loaned it to a friend who says he is now going to buy one so I thought Id see if Amazon still carries it and I read some reviews I was shocked by some of the critical comments I read This stove heats water very quickly even at high altitudes though water will not heat as quickly at 10000 feet as it will at sea level with any stove Compared to a white gas stove or a Jetboil this stove does heat slightly more slowly but the difference is negligible and not worth the 100 difference in price and putting up with the delicate craftsmanship of the others This Coleman is solid and durable The head has many small holes or jets for the flame to ensure a regular evenlydistributed level adjustable with clicks on the dial from high to very low simmering to off with a couple more stops in between The design of the burner shields the flame from any wind so in all but the most windy conditions it works fine without any additional shielding Mine simmers perfectly with a very small flame Some reviewers here complained that the simmer is too strong so they may have a defective unit If I were to design a stove I would design the flame control as utilitarian as this one is The burner easily separates from the tank and base to split up the load for hiking The tanks can be found for just a few dollars and Coleman claims a tank will last for more than two hours on high or nine hours on low which is plenty to cook many meals and heat water for cleanup Ive used it to prepare all meals for a threeday backpacking trip for six people at 9000 feet and I didnt use up a single tank I suggest starting with a full tank or two depending on length of trip backpacking and keeping partial tanks to use on camping trips where having extra tanks is not an issue For the price this is a steal Its a very good stove for backpacking and for camping though a little heavy for the hiker Not a problem for a group however to distribute the load Remember when youre a couple days in at 10000 feet you want a good reliable and durable stove like this  and not a finicky white gas or specialcanister overpriced butane stove

My old camp stove broke not a Coleman so I went searching for a new one that would be equal to the task My old one was smaller and I think the BTU output was less because it would take forever to heat water on it This one is quite powerful It is larger by far so my cast iron skillet fits better on it Used a camp stove griddle with both burners going it keeps the griddle pretty evenly heated I loved that my pancakes turned out so evenly cooked The only down side that I noticed is that when the thing is new it is a little difficult keeping the flame turned down low enough not to burn stuff I would turn the nob down a bit and the nob would not stay where I put it Once it warmed up and after a couple of uses I was able to get the flame more closely to how I wanted it to keep from burning things oh and for those that complain that this does not have room to store bottles of propane in it OF COURSE NOT No propane cook stove does that that I know of Only the white gasliquid fuel ones do that

This little kit is indispensable when setting up and taking down a big tent like I have The stake puller and rubber hammer makes the task easier And everyone wants to use the little broom and dustpan 
I get a kick out of reviewers here who deduct stars because they are surprised by the specs which are plainly displayed Yes the base is the size it is in the pic The burner is wide so your pans dont fall off And the regulator sticks out so its bulkier to pack It sits high just like in the pic so if somebody wobbles a picnic table it will tip over And no its not designed for backpacking do people know they also have to pack a bulky bottle to go with it Been using this for two Summers now Its a breeze to set up No builtin ignitor is fine by me  the less crap and gizmos they put on these things the less that will go wrong and the less you rely on said crap and gizmos It will boil a large pot of coffee in 5 minutes at 10000 feet A 12 pan sits just fine unattended on the large oversized burner but you have to stir more often from the middle  out 10 pans are perfect The flame is powerful and consistent you can tell just by the sound it makes The low setting is fine for simmering The regulator is NOT variable because you dont want to accidentally turn it off forcing you to relight over and over again Bottles screw in easily Its just the right height to sit on the ground and Ive never had it tip over If youre paranoid just put a couple of rocks on the base For those of you that cook in the wind newsflash Wind and fire do not mix Wind will carry the heat away Get a wind screen Ive been through at least 20 bottles on this thing It works the same way every time I just store it in a cheap vinyl bag I got somewhere For longer trips with 4 people this stove compliments a 2 burner stove perfectly 
Bought two of these for car camping instead of a 2 burner camp stove I figured these would be easier to pack up I found from two days using them it is difficult to know how low you can cut it before it goes out when you already have a pan on top cooking but that probably goes for any camp stove Both mornings it was breezy and raining and the wind was blowing across on the flames so I had to have the gas turned up relatively high Fortunately with the power these things provide I had no problem finishing the bacon Having them set on top of a picnic table a pan tip over twice due to other people moving while sitting at the table While they work fine I think I would have been better off with the dual burner camp stove for the stability of a lower cooking surface and the wind protection they provide I plan on making a plywood base to secure the two propane tanks and maybe a cooking grate to avoid any more tip overs

Review for Coleman PerfectFlow 1Burner Stove Uses 1lb propane cylinder This is an indirect criticism The burner works fine and seems solid Lots of heat output and apparently well made The problem is storing it If the design had been though out just a little bit better the plastic stable base would pack more closely with the burnerreflector assemble to make a smaller package I may try cutting 4 slots in the base to allow that It wouldnt be a big thing  The alternate might be to have some form of foldup feet that would allow the base to pack inside the reflector You can buy aftermarket stable bases that have swivel feet to reduce the diameter for storage 
Every time I use this I get exited about how well it is designed Setup is easy and you can get the net very tight easily It slowly loosens over time but a quick tug and youre back to perfect again Only improvement would be longer stakes if youre playing in sand The trick is to loosen the lines so your stakes are far from the net and at a 45 degree angle from the side linethen scoop away as much sand as possible to get down to more solid ground then angle the stakes back toward the pole and drive them as far as you can into the sand with a hammer Do it right from the start otherwise youll just be fighting it all day as the stakes pull out Plastic tent stakes work a little better than these stakes as long as you make sure you angle them back to the pole Anyways I highly doubt there is a better net out there in this price range

We have had this stove for a while and it has been a good one We dont use it often but it has always performed the way you would expect it to We used to live in the county and we had numerous power failures and in one bad winter storm that meant 3 days without power This little stove helped cook our meals and keep us going during that time period The stove sets up easy and the two burners are ideal to cook a larger meal with two things going at once The flame controls work well and you have good control over the heat setting you want to use which is important whether you are trying to boil water or make eggs for breakfast I also like how the cover and side wind shields lock together and help keep the flame steady and hold in the heat We always have some cylinders of propane around and they are inexpensive and easy to find The grill features an InstaStart spark igniter but to be honest I always carry matches or butane lighter as a backup The propane cylinder lasts a reasonable amount of time and the specs say 11 hours on high and 45 hours on low when using a 164 ounce propane cylinder with both burners going We always got that same usage or a little better This baby gets things hot fast and you dont need to use the full burner setting all the time We have been very happy with ours and it is ideal for camping or those emergency times when you lose power This is a very good product and I recommend it to you

As an avid camper and outdoors person I use my tent quit a bit and the only way to make a tent last is to make sure that you take really good care of it and this kit will definitely help you do that for sure The kit comes in a nice little mesh bag and includes four extra heavy duty tent stakes a convenient tent stake puller for those ones that dont want to come out of the ground easily a very nice quality rubber mallet to help drive tent stakes into rougher terrain like we have here in Oklahoma and my favorite part of the package is the nice little hand broom and dust pan for sweeping out the inside of the tent before you roll it up and pack it back in the bag for the next trip All in all this is a very nice addition to have in your camping gear for all of those excellent summer camping trips And as always when it comes to camping gear Coleman never lets me down with there quality products

My dad had some Coleman gear when I was a kid about 40 years ago but I havent gone camping in those intervening decades so had no idea what had happened with the legendary Coleman name in all this time As soon as I pulled this stove out of its carefullypacked box I could see that they still were building highquality equipment The stove sets up within a couple of minutes and provides a very stable base Stability is of paramount importance if youre going to use it in realitybased situations instead of on the back porch because nature is not flat nor smooth in most places In a disaster or other emergency things are dark confused and in a huge mess one of the last things you need is for some of your dwindling food supply to topple over while the stove happily starts your shelter on fire That will not happen with this Coleman stove on the ground The two gas valves are large for precise flame control and have a silky feel to them The off position cinches the valves down tight The lid and side wind shields hook together and stay that way until you want them to come apart The chrome grill comes off easily for cleaning Propane for this stove is inexpensive and readily available at our local stores You can disconnect a partiallyused propane cylinder and use it again later I got this one to add to our emergency gear for when the next power outage hits wish Id done it two outages ago

A little tempermental in that it can get extremely hot in seconds Not a bad thing though If you want to be able to turn the water on and off throughout your shower experience without having to turn the unit on and off you can install a valve on the hose But you must be sure to install a bypass valve that allows the water to go somewhere otherwise you WILL burn up your pump The water needs to continually flow Best way for me was to follow example of a very helpful you tube vide guy in garage where he used an open mouthed jug instead of the bladder bag it comes with He rigged his system with a bypass valve that routed the water back to the jug when not spraying through the nozzle Not only does this recycle your water so you dont waste any from letting in spill on the floor when not using it soaping up but it saves your pump AND sends heated water back to the water source where your thermostat senses it Guess what happens You burn less gas heating water because the reccyling effect sends hot water back to the source and you end up with a bucket of hot water pretty much set to the temperature you desire CAnt beat this product at all Read all the positive reviews that offer lessons learned If you follow their examples and advice you will definitely enjoy this product Mine did not leak anywhere BECAUSE I did not block water flow Blocking water flow with a simple on off valve instead of a bypass valve causes pressure to build up in the pump and in the unit You have to imagine that building up pressure in anything is not good Be sure to rig a three way bypass system that allows water to flow in one way and out two ways nozzle line or second line that runs back to water source or wherever else you want it to go Enjoy this product because you can Also the best way to use this product for us was in a twosided shower tent We had the unit propped up on a simple stool on the dry side near the door so we could easily reach out of the shower side and make water temperature adjustments Having it outside the stall like the guy in the you tube video did not work for us as we could not control the water temperature on the fly With a recirculating water setup you are going to want to have this level of control because the hot water will return to the jug and you may get some of that back doubly hot unless you turn down your temperature setting just right Plus the space a double stall affords just makes your outdoor camping shower experience that much more pleasant day or night battery operated lanterns inside stalls 
Waiting for spring to take this out of the box but I love the idea that I already have it and can put it up when the kids are looking for something entertaining to do 
This is a really great system One of the higher quality outdoor nets that dont take an hour to set up However when i set it all up the boundary lines were WAY TOO BIG It was a good 2 feet bigger on all sides I had to knot each corner off to make it the correct length Outside of that great system 
My entire family plays volleyball and when it was finally time for us to buy our own net system we turned to ParkNSun based on our long familiarity with their systems at numerous grass volleyball tournaments over the years We chose the Spectrum Classic as a balance between a competition quality system and affordability Set up is super easy and the net affords a decent amount of play It is not as tight as a fully competitive system so digging a ball out of the bottom of the net is possible but not consistent Similarly net serves into the top tape behave differently than say a steel cable reinforced indoor net However the net does not sag and the blue vinyl is great for visibility The entire system is well made and appears to be quite durable even the travel bag The lines provided with the system are typical corded nylon rope We opted to upgrade the lines with competition grade flat tape lines from VolleyballUSAcom which are adjustable to the smaller FIVB court as well as the traditional court sizes

This catalytic propane heater is adequate for a very small area such as a hunting blind but it does not put out enough heat for use as an emergency heater at home or for an RV There are other larger more expensive catalyst propane heaters available that you could use for those applications if you pay attention to the safety precautions With this heater the propane burns very efficiently in the catalyst disc so carbon monoxide production is greatly reduced However the instructions caution that you still must provide a ventilation opening to outside air for oxygen and to vent any carbon monoxide The earlier instructions included with this heater model and the similar older matchlit version strangely did not mention the necessary breakin period I think some reviewers say the instructions now cover this You must initially run this heater for a number of hours outside or in a vented garge to get rid of an initial bad smell Its probably best to burn a whole small propane bottle If you dont do this you could have a very unpleasant experience breathing in whatever smelly stuff it burns off the new catalyst disc for the first few hours After that it will only have a very slight musty odor that is not too noticeable if you use adequate ventilation as the instructions say However if you are sensitive to odors this could be still be a problem There is no flame and the combustion takes place inside the catalyst disc but you still must be careful not to put it near flammable items due to the high radiant heat right above the the screencovered disc

I didnt have any design or function problems with my unit at all It worked fine right out of the box For my purpose heating a tent or a small bedroom in case of a power outage Id buy it again and the price is right BTW the Winter temps in northwest WA are usually pretty mild at sea level so although the 1500 BTU output isnt much it is all I need The very first time I lit my unit I was puzzled why it took 5 or 6 clicks of the instastart spark to light it even though Coleman predicts this in their instructions By telling you to start clicking the spark right after opening the valve I suspect Coleman is making sure you dont let a large amount of propane build up before you hit the button In other words I suspect it takes the same amount of time to click the starter 5 or 6 times as for the unit to build up enough propane to light When it does there is a small poof of blue and yellow flame True if you waited a few minutes after you open the valve to click the starter one click might be enough to light the unit but you might also lose your eyebrows or worse One thing for sure run your heater outside or maybe in your garage for a LONG time when it is brand new In fact Id say use up a whole container of propane to break it in The reason for this is that the smell this heater puts out when it is new is nasty Ever get a rug stuck in the rotating brush of your vacuum cleaner and the rubber drive belt starts to smoke Well its like that smell TIMES TEN I couldnt find any mention of the odor or warnings about toxicity in the Coleman booklet so Coleman must not think is is harmful But believe me it sure is unpleasant and Coleman should mention the idea of breaking in the heater when new After I ran about 34 of a tank of propane through my new heater the smell was completely gone But fair warning break this puppy in before you bring it inside with you Otherwise no complaints and Id buy it again and recommend it to you Stay warm out there

If youre a real trekker carrying all your gear tent food and water then this is not the product for you These are very heavyduty tent stakes suitable for a very large tent or for securing a tent that is going to be in very windy weather They are big and heavy way too much for lightweight or weightconscious camping That being said in the threeodd years Ive had these stakes they go in and they stay in This is for hand placement or a stomp with a boot If youre using a hammer and you run these things down into the earth they are as secure as you can get and its going to take a tornado to take your tent away But surprisingly they have always come out very easily They usually come out with a simple hand pull or I just hook one stake into the other and they come out with this method I have experienced absolutely no bending with these stakes They have not even had their blades bent or warped from emplacement or removal They are very tough very sturdy and will retain their shape My only complaint is that they stain very easily and quickly After one campout there was considerable staining on all stakes from contat with earth They always clean up easily in hot water with a quick brush They still work fine and still have not rusted but they are very blotchy as the staining is blackdark gray This staining has had no effect on performance Bottom line for car camping or other equipmentheavy camping or for use where your tent or fly or shelter needs to be secure this is a great purchase well worth the price But for true trekking and hikeinout camping these are really more than you need

I bought this stove primarily to use for emergencies or when I experience a power outage but I like that I can also use it for camping note it is not a backpacking stove its too bulky and propane is too heavy for that I was a bit surprised that the base is a lot larger than it looks in the online picture This stove can accommodate 12 and even 14 pots and pans While this may seem like a positive for me I wish it was slightly smaller At least it can be stored in a cupboard vertically I also wish the stove came with a carrying pouch or case but it does not The stove performs and functions perfectly well and seems sturdy and well built so all in all for the price Im happy with it despite the few negatives Ive mentioned Small propane tanks are cheap and readily available for about 150200 which is a real plus 
We bought a new coleman stove and thought a grill would make cooking outside easier This fits it perfectly Now we can make pancakes and other things on the griddle instead of a pan Much easier cleanup 
This griddle is specifically designed to work with a STOVEGRIDDLE model by Coleman ONLY If you use it on a Coleman StoveGriddle model stove it works great If you purchase this griddle to use on any other propane model Coleman stove it wont fit If you purchase this to use on a classic pump up liquid fuel Coleman stove it wont fit It is ONLY designed to work with a late model grillstove with two gas valves on far opposite sides It probably wont even fit the green colored early model grillstove with the two red gas valves on the same side All that being said you have been warned The griddle works great for pancakes eggs fish burgers sausage But if you plan to cook bacon youre going to have to deal with the grease while you are cooking There is not enough channel to catch the grade from one pound of bacon You will have to dump grease while you are cooking Be ready The only other issue is that this thing is made of aluminum If youre not cooking it can melt if left on the stove with a flame I dont know how the engineer that decided to make this thing out of aluminum instead of cast iron remains employed at Coleman That is just ridiculous While it does work its will melt easily if not watched or removed form the stove immediately after cooking

This is an allaround great lantern for camping Its really bright when its turned up but in most cases you wont need that much so you can turn it down and expect quite a bit more time out of it But it is nice to have the extra brightness when you need it  I havent seen an electric one that can even come close Yeah the base can come off pretty easily but I dont mind it too much I only use the base when its sitting on something anyway right If Im carrying it around I just leave the base behind Often times I will hang the lantern up high to increase its lighting distance and I dont need the base in those cases either 
I keep this lantern handy for power outages I plan to take it camping next time I go I recommend keeping the Styrofoam case that protects the glass globe Its much easier to dismantle and store the unit without fear of breaking the globe This twomantle lantern throws out lots of light It starts easily with a match I dont like the way the propane tank sits in the base To move the lantern from one room to the next you must support the plastic base otherwise it falls off Very important Do not overtighten the top ventilator nut The glass globe will crack because it has no room to expand when it heats up I cracked two globes before contacting Coleman who showed me the error of my ways Despite the problems this is a great lantern and its much easier to use than Colemans pump version that uses liquid fuel UPDATE October 2011 I still use the same lantern for camping and power outages UPDATE February 2017 The lantern stills works beautifully Weve changed the mantle a few times but thats expected This Coleman still goes with us on every camping trip And despite the arguments I receive from some readers of my reviews we use this lantern indoors to light our way during a power outage The best part is that we never have to worry about deadweak batteries when a storm unexpectedly knocks out the power We keep a couple of propane tanks on hand at all times

Classic lantern Just like when I was a kid Worked great Very bright even on low setting 
What can I say it is a lantern sort of like the old Coleman fuel lantern but it burns propane Fairly bright the higher up you have the better it light the night Im nostalgic for the lanterns of old but I have to admit this version does everything they did No fuel to spill it burns great you can adjust the light output and it breaks down to a small size without the tank I set this up a home with the mantles packed it away and went camping at a campground with no electricity when night came and I wanted light out came the lantern On the first night when I turned down the light because I didnt need it at full throttle it whistled for about two seconds on low the next two nights it didnt make the sound at all A few things to remember folks this thing uses combustion to light it burns propane keep it away from flammable material it will get hot dont use it in an enclosed space and allow it to cool before putting in a tent for overnight storage Also those little battery lanterns headband lights and flashlights make better walking around the campground lights

Generates I bought this one burner propane stove for a very specialized need roasting green coffee beans in a cast iron skillet outside Due to the smoke that roasting coffee beans produce roasting inside is not an option so I roast on my deck and needed a heat source All you need to fire up the Coleman Powerpack is a small propane tank priced at 2 for about 7 I roasted green coffee beans today and the Powerpack generated more than enough heat to raise the temperature in the skillet to over 400F the optimal temperature for roasting coffee beans Delighted to have the Powerback for my coffee roasting hobby 
it does the tricknot for simmering a sauce but for skillet cooking and boiling its greati have noticed in pictures of the stove everybody sets the propane stove at the odd side angle try setting the propane bottle so the bottom sticks straight up in the airyou will find it sets flush on table and more stable which is how i think it was designed to do

This is the ticket It does require a wrench to install to bottle unlike picture shows but no big deal This along with a hose will eliminate the 1 lb bottles all together 
Today I used a batterypowered pump purchased for under ten dollars at the grocery store of all places to inflate this for the first time It is true that it takes some guesswork to assemble the paddles correctly Basically the instructions dont explain that the closed end of the poles is where you attach the paddles this creates a seal and then water doesnt seep into the poles Anyway since it was the first time it probably took 10 minutes or more to inflate but the process was very simple The air chambers are numbered so you know which part to inflate first Its a little tricky closing the plugs without letting all the air out because it is built to deflate quickly My sisterinlaw made the smart decision of keeping the pump running and then quickly pulling it out and closing the plug In any case its very manageable Then we took it out into the pond on a day windy enough for whitecaps We could not believe how well it tracked It actually has two skegs which my quite expensive real kayak lacks The paddles do drip but again compared to my hundreddollar real paddle the price of this entire inflatable package they do an excellent job Just plan to get a bit wet bathing suit bottoms recommended My 82yearold dad who has been avoiding tippy canoes and cant get in my real kayak at all came with me and he LOVED it It was so nice to be able to get him back on the water again My sixyearold did not come with meit was really too windybut I tried both the front and back seats myself and I feel confident that she will be able to sit very securely in the front seat Even as the waves bounced us up and down the kayak felt very sturdy I really cant say enough good things about this kayak My only advice would be that if you plan to paddle alone often you might want to consider a singlethis one is surprisingly large One middleaged and one elderly thumbsup

Ive been using Coleman propane lanterns since I was a teenager and Ive loved every one and kept most of them for years and years As much hassle as real mantels can be they emit the most pure and brightest light I can imagine Ive bought and owned several batternpowere lantern but none comes close to propane for sheer illumination If youre camping alone in a relatively remote area its nice to put this lantern on a rock or tree stump and have good vision for quite a distance easily 50 if youre burning on high power As someone else mentioned I think there needs to be a better way to attach the base though sometimes I just stick the propane tank in a pile of gravel or dirt and its pretty steady so that you can move the lantern quickly I also miss the tieon mantles though it took me a long time to get good at tying them I rarely use propane indoors but with winter coming here to New England I love having a super bright lantern like this to set out on the front step to make the neighborhood more cheery when the power goes away

I recently purchased the Coleman Dry Gear Bag size Small  24 x 10 from Amazon for a 4wheeling trip to West Virginia As it turned out I didnt really need to use it but in case it rained I wanted to have it with me As usual the shipping from Amazon was speedy and I received the bag in under a week Unfortunately I wish I had taken more time to look at my local Bass Pro shop first This bag is around a 20oz bag which I found to be almost too small for what I neededwanted it for Its also a very stiff bag The little loops that are attached are nice as is the translucent seethru nature of the plastic But in terms of overall construction quality its not as nice as a 30oz bag I could have gotten locally for around 12 Honestly Im not 100 certain that this bag would be the best if there were a chance of it getting submerged or sitting in standing water After putting items in mine and rolling it I could still push air out That tells me the seal wasnt very solidcomplete Conversely I have a small a datahookproductlinklinked classalinknormal hrefSealLineBajaDryBagsSpring2010dpB0009RNVPArefcmcrarpdrvwtxtieUTF8SealLine Baja Dry Bags Spring 2010a bag that I can NOT do that on And the bag I tried out at Bass Pro could have doubled as a pillow with the way it held air In the end its caveat emptor You get what you are paying for with this bag If you are looking for something cheap and simple just to keep the rain or mud off of your stuff then this might be a good choice for a relatively low price But if you are looking for something that is more durable and airtight Id encourage you to take a look at some of your other options both on Amazon and at stores like Bass Pro or Cavenders

I like to camp but Im not what you would call an avid camper I usually go tenting with my family about two to three weekends a year I did not really purchase this stove for that purpose even though Im sure it will come in handy I purchased this stove for emergency use Things like if the electric goes out government takeover you know the whole conspiracy crazy agenda end of world stuff LOL After looking up a TON of reviews I ended up buying two of these stovesburners I couldnt be happier after testing These stoves light easy heat fast easy to clean and will hold big pans with ease I also think they are much safer than a lot of the stoves Ive looked at It is true that they do not have a windblock but that is a easy fix if you have half a brain to set up something if you are using outdoors Another thing about these is in a pinch and even though not recommended they are a source of heat These babies put off some nice warmth Again make sure you have a carbon monoxide detector if you choose to do that but again they can serve that purpose in a major crisis What really sold me on this burner was the youtube video I am linking on here  Even though the YT video is somewhat cheesy and long this guy went through the gambit with testing this stove from boiling carbon dioxidemonoxide temperature etc After all of the reviews he literally sold this stove to me Coleman needs to pay whoever this guy is Anyways just get the stove In fact get two if you are a prepper for a backup and for an extra source of heat if in a critical situation

We bought these bags to use on a canoe trip to protect our gear It turns out weve ended up using them for our regular boating trips when we want to assure that anything water sensitive cameras phones etc are protected They are nice and firm not too mushy I really like that they are clear so we can see whos items are in which we have several The yellow tabs are lashing tabs and we use those when on canoe trips to make sure they dont get away You can use a Carabineer to lash and remove them easily or run a rope right through under the tab This bag is pretty small and good for small items such as cameras a wallet and other small electronics If you want to put some clothes and a towel in too try the larger 29x13 bagnbspa datahookproductlinklinked classalinknormal hrefColeman29x13DryGearBagdpB0009PUT70refcmcrarpdrvwtxtieUTF8Coleman 29x13 Dry Gear Baga Thatll give you enough room to have what you need and roll the top down to seal the bag too The sizes are before closing so by the time you close it up theres less space than anticipated

Works as well as any other two burner propane lantern After trying the PerfectFlow valve I dont like it as well as the plain old screw valve The PerfectFlow valve is a fourposition valve off low medium high I can see where the inexperienced user might like that I prefer the fine continuous control of a screw valve which allows me to dial the light very low to be an all night nightlight You cant do that with the PerfectFlow valve Other than that this is a typical two burner propane lantern

This is a great boat In its deflated form it can fit under a modestly high bed or in a closet With a pump it inflates in about 5 minutes It isnt too heavy though might be a bit much for a child It wont go fast but goes faster than you might think On calm water it is surprising easy to power and maneuver The going gets rough with even a little bit of current The paddles come in sections that you screw together They are adequate for calm water Buyer Beware for stronger current I was recently paddling against a minor current in Biscayne Bay and one of the plastic pieces where you place your hands snapped in two Fortunately the person in front wasnt too heavy as I had to use their paddle to get back In summery great convenient boat but dont depend on the paddles 
My wife and I took this Coleman inflatable kayak out for the first time today on Lake Ray Hubbard in the DFW area I received it Wednesday in a very compact box and inside it had the kayak instructions and 2 kayaking oars that came in 7 pieces each These went together quickly and come with collars that separate each oar into 3 pieces for easy transport and storage When I unfolded the kayak for the first time I was really amazed at just how big it is Im 62 and my wife is 57 Both of us fit very comfortably and there is probably enough leg room for someone up to about 66 or so to feel really comfortable There is a storage area in the front and the back thats triangular in shape We brought along some snacks and drinks in a plastic bag but Id be willing to bet you could get a small cooler in there as well As for performance on the water it worked better than I had expected We launched from the shore over some floating debris and the sides barely displaced 2 of water with a combined weight of 320 between us It was very stable to get into and out of because its wide and has seems that allow the side air pockets to pivot and stay still while the bottom moves as you move around It was a little slow over the water because of the same width and its also because of the width that I have my only gripe The included oars are a bit short for the size of this boat which means you are going to get wet if you plan on getting anywhere in a decent amount of time you are forced to swing the oars over so far that the opposite oar drips right on top of you We did encounter some boat wake and it took that no problem straight on and at an angle I would not be surprised if it even took a parallel wake without flipping It just feels that stable I wouldnt recommend taking it out in a lot of chop however the kayak does move and gyrate a whole lot when you encounter different levels of water Blowing up and packing couldnt be any easier I bought an Ozark Trail large volume hand pump from Walmart to make my life easier and I was able to fully inflate the kayak in just over 6 minutes from empty There are numbers on each of the 8 valves that tell you the order to inflate in Deflating for me was as easy as undoing all of the valves and rolling the kayak one way then unrolling and rolling the other way It collapsed on its own to a size small enough for even the smallest trunk I expect to get a lot of use out of the kayak this summer Its very fast to set up and a lot of fun just remember that the oars are going to get you wet

Id put this stove up against any camping stove Small enough to pack but big enough to put large pots or skillets on Works on camping fuel or unleaded gasoline Works great 
I just tried this out and I like it BUT I do want to answer the people that could not get it lit I couldnt either Until I watched a youtube video It seems the instructions arent very clear about opening up the priming pump It says to turn it to open and hold your thumb over the end when I did this I couldnt push it in and pump After watching the video I finally realized that I wasnt turning the end to the open position It must be turned counter anti clockwise about 3 times before it is truly open Only then can you hold your thumb over the hole and prime it 30 times once I did this it fired right up So dont think its going to break because you feel tension when turning it to open it just use some force on it when turning it to open and then it works great Also remember to slowly release the pressure when undoing the filler cap or it will explode gas out

I bought this inflatable kayak primarily because several local adventure races require softsided boats It turns out to be one of the best 100 purchases ever and Im using it much more than I had originally thought I love the ease of rolling it up tossing it in the car trunk and being ready to hit the water almost anywhere Ive used it in the Gulf of Mexico in the bay and little inlets and it handles pretty well even with a nonpaddling passenger Its a fun way to poke around the wetlands do some birding etcwith its shallow draft you can paddle in literally inches of water Because it is wider and flatter than most kayaks the wind will push it a bit but its fairly responsive and maneuverable even fully loaded Definitely spring for the rechargable inflator which does the job in less than five minutes The paddles could be better but theyre OK for the money This kayak is a great option for someone whod like to paddle sometimes but doesnt want the hassle of storing a kayak strapping it to the roof of their car or dragging it to a launching spot The price works out to be about the same as just a couple days of kayak rentals and it opens up so many possibilities of kayaking where there arent any rentals

Me and some buddies go camping once a year and I the camping guru would always bring the battery operated bulb lanterns Well this past year a friend brought along one of these and the difference was staggering If you turn that dial as high as it goes you can practically simulate daylight He put it on a stand and we were able to spot a snake that was ironically closest to my lantern Needless to say I purchased one of my own the first chance I got I prefer this model to the selfignition version due to the fact that the more handson something is the more proficient one becomes in using it Also it will be easier to spot when something is wrong with the unit this way The last thing one wants to discover is that something has rendered their lantern useless that could very well have been predicted and fixed before the next outing Insofar as the base goes I have done away with the flaps that come with it and fashioned my own out of a paint can I sprayed it with Rustoleum and then cut a hole in the top to barely accommodate the propane cylinder and flared out the base in order to create a near indestructible base that weighs practically nothing and can be strapped to the outside of a pack without worry about rust I also went so far as to keep a carabiner on hand to attach to the handle and along with some 550 cord I am able to affix it to any tree should the need arise This has come in handy for those times when I have lost a race against the sun and still have a couple miles to go before making it the distance I had planned to travel for the day before resting When these times strike I attach it to a propane hose and keep the tank in my backpack to better accommodate the weight so I can keep the light held high for longer I have even from time to time attached it to a stick to hold out before me to better show the terrain and judge elevation better I keep another one at home permanently affixed to a hose w a stand along with some 20lb propane canisters for whenever the weather knocks out power Ill have a strong light source to keep working and have even used it to show my way when shoveling snow at night To the point This lantern is one of those purchases that will always come in handy It can be used for emergency home situations and outdoor alike Keep an eye on the mantles and when they go on sale stock up You may never need all of them but they will at least be around in case you do Finally a word of WARNING This lantern can get hot enough to ignite or melt nearby objects For this reason it would not be very safe to use in a tent or around combustible items I have seen people pinched in an emergency use this as a tent heater needless to say Id have to be in a very difficult situation before I attempted going down that same route I definitely wouldnt fall asleep in a tent with this on

I bought this tent kit mostly because of the Coleman name I needed a solid mallet and stake remover and this was a great deal for the price The mallet itself is sturdy and works like a charm I prefer a mallet over a hammer because I hate the metalonmetal of certain tent spikes it tends to ruin both items Tent spikes are a dime a dozen and if you hit one wrong or camp on hard dirt youll break your spikes no matter who you invest in These hold up well for the price The only two downfalls to this set is the bag itself and the broom While you do have covers for the tent spikes those are easy to lose and once lost the spikes quickly begin poking through the bag itself so I store them elsewhere The broom and dustpan are just cheap If you really need a broom invest in a better one or use a small handheld batterypowered vacuum The bag works for storage for everything else that comes with the tent kit with no issues

UPDATE I have had this stove for 3 years now and have used it quite a lot and have never had a problem with it We are also just bought our second camper which has a suburban propane stove hooked to a 25 pound propane bottle and we still take this little guy along with us set it up on the picnic table and cook outdoors I just couldnt be happier with this little guy Everything I said in my original review still holds true Original Review below is still valid I havent had this stove long but I just cooked dinner on it and did a review Go to Youtube and type in themarkfellows2 and look for my review It will be uploaded tonight and ready for viewing in the morning I cooked a large pot of Chicken Egg Drop soup and it performed great with plenty of power from the main burnerI didnt use the auxiliary burner but I am sure it is fine I boiled 8 cups of chicken broth 2 cups of water and cooked 2 pounds of chicken and vegetables in about 30 minutes Start to finish The stove lights and works very well The Auxiliary burner is easy to light and extinguish I used Coleman fuel that was AT LEAST 10 years old and maybe 20 years old and left first in a porch exposed to cold and heat and sunlight It burned just fine I have found Coleman fuel to be Extremely stable Propane is more stable and burns cleaner but I just can not justify using those little 1 pound bottles and then chucking them in the trash when they are empty It just seems really stupid to me to use those If they have an adapter to make one of those propane stoves use a 20 pound bottle more power to you I will stick with liquid fuel if I can It generates much less waste than the 1 pound bottles and you can get fuel anywhere Plus this can run on gasoline if you wish Anyway back to the stove It is great It lights easily has plenty of power has great fine adjustment on the heat and burns very steadily after the first five minutes and the generator heats up This will be a fine stove for my car camping I already have an MSR Dragonfly for backpacking One big plus was that it was manufactured in the USA That means a lot to me over Chinese goods Be aware though the first couple times you use it you will likely burn some paint off so you will smell burning paint fumes a little if you have the burner turned up high Also the stove body gets hot so keep stuff that will melt away from it I put a video on youtube where I cook a pot of soup with 20 year old coleman fuel Go to youtube and look for the suburban hippie survivalist and look for my video on it Good luck Mark

I received the stove yesterday No problems with shipping or packaging I purchased a 1 gallon can of Coleman fuel at WalMart for about 7 The stove came with a filter funnel which made filling easy The stove instructions were a little hard to read but this is a simple product I pumped the stove about 40 pumps to pressurize the stove I lit the stove and there was very high yellow flames initially so keep your windscreen out of the way so you dont overheat the paint I opened up both burners and let it rock for 35 minutes Soon the wild yellow flame disappeared and I got a nice blue flame I turned the stove off and it burned out in 30 seconds It is a small cooking area If you are hosting a large camp site and plan to be using very large pots and pans you might want to look at the 3 burner This would be fine for a small base camp with small to medium size cookware This would easily serve well for a 24 person camp I liked that the instructions were posted on a sticker inside the lid They show it being lit with a match but i think it would be safer and easier to use a long lighter if you have one WalMart had the stove for 7800 with tax it would be about 8500 It was 8800 online 7800 in store One last but important note The instructions say you can use unleaded fuel if necessary It is the if necessary language that bothers me That is legal speak for you can use unleaded fuel but we prefer you to use Coleman fuel If that is the case you might be better off just buying the stove that operates on Coleman fuel I saw a post that talked about unleaded fuel containing ethanol corroding the seals but I cant verify this Overall a good piece of equipment Happy trails

Yes campers this is the one to buy The same kind of green metal stove that Grampa couldnt break Sure its not quite as sturdy as the old ones but its still pretty darn rugged And you can use the same stuff you dump in the car to fire it no nonrefillable tank to mess with It heats a pot of water to boiling almost as fast as my fancy kitchen range If you cant cook it on a Coleman 2 Burner Dual Fuel Compact Liquid Fuel Stovedont eat it 
I just bought a second one of these for my folks to have for car camping and earthquake preparedness I have had the other one for over ten years and it just keeps on fine These are very durable little stoves They are easy to use  except that you need a match or lighter and are very stable Certainly much more so than the 1 burner camping stoves you see for backpacking etc As far as the requiring a match its actually just simpler that way You can always find matches at a store but you wont often find the replacement parts for an ignitor unit when it finally needs to be replaced  A lot of people like the propane stoves but then they waste a lot of those expensive canisters A ten dollar gallon can of fuel for this thing will last as longer than 15 of the propane tanks for most stoves And of course being able to run it on unleaded gasoline in an emergency is a very useful feature for earthquake emergency preparedness I have actually used my stove for weeks on end while camping If you are in an emergency situation this will allow you to boil water and still make good hot food when your gas line or electricity is out There is enough space that you can use pretty decent size pots and pans For instance when I make my spaghetti and italian sausage there is plenty of room to boil the water in a big pot while cooking up the italian sausage in a skillet right next to it If you are really worried about space have a big family etc than you should consider the three burner variant of this stove If you are a car camper or want a good little stove for emergency situations this is the one for you
