I wanted propane because I already have a lot of other propane style cookware for camping aside from a few older Coleman camp stoves that require liquid fuel Its good for the morning to make coffee if your grillstove is already being used to cook breakfast I was originally debating a smaller MSR or Jetboil style single burner for the smaller size but I decided to go with this one It is probably to big to pack for hikes considering you have the larger burner and the 1 lb propane bottle 
Ive owned many camp stoves over the past half century cheap and expensive ones Been using this one regularly for seven years or so and its possibly the best singleburner stove Ive used for car camping  Unlike most singleburners its large footprint rubber feet and low profile make it very stable especially with larger pots  pans This makes it safer than others important if youve got kids around Nothing more disappointing than having a nice pot of chili cooking and have it tip over into little Johnnys lap  Easy to set up and get cooking right away No liquid fuel to spill no odor no pumping or waiting for a generator to heat up Ive used it in windy conditions and its rarely blown out  Easy to clean Many stoves have a lot of exposed parts on top that catch spilled food This one doesnt The large painted surface around the burner stays relatively cool so I havent had to scrub any burned food It just wipes off  Very sturdy Ive used heavy cast iron pots without fear of crushing it The pot supports go down to the feet rather than into the stove itself  A few tips  This stove can simmer fairly well at the lowest setting and has a large diameter burner that spreads the heat heat out better than smaller ones However a simple diffuser plate many available here on Amazon on top of the burner helps this and most other type stove keep from scorching food in the center of the pan Very useful if using thin aluminum camping pots  A little powdered graphite applied to the threads of the propane fitting makes it easier to thread the bottle into it  Protect the fittings of the propane tube assembly form dirtdamage I keep the assembly in a ziplock bag Be careful not to crossthread the bottle when screwing it into the fitting  Propane isnt as cheap as liquid Coleman fuel for the same heat output but at 2 for a 1 propane bottle that will generally last for many hours cooking not bad No need for the expensive little proprietary cans that other stoves use Can also be hooked up to a larger tank if need be  This is a great item for anyone wanting to simplify their camp cooking Cant say enough good about it

This saw is only for light and infrequent use The nut loosens and needs locktite Other reviewers are correct that the blade opens on its own and the locking tab bent on mine also The saw gets jammed very easily causing the blade to bend I had to straighten it several times after using it during a 4 day hike While cutting some overgrown vines the plastic handle cracked at the forward tip and it fell apart I have the incredible Dollar General folding saw and it works much better  got it on clearance for 1 It stays closed locks open better and the blade is much more durable than the Coleman The blade is a bit thicker and you can realy power through a good sized chunk of wood without the blade bending  sorry Coleman but I have to keep it real here 
The saw worked moderately well but was a little whimpy If the wood was very dry it cut right through If the wood was wet or green it was very difficult not to bend the blade while working It is compact and light and will be utilized for years to come 
Ok generally the Coleman name makes me think of affordable yet tough and rugged equipment or at least it did till I got this FLIMSY PIECE OF JUNK Im sure itll saw just fine but my problem is the darned thing DOES NOT STAY SHUT If I have a folding knife or saw in this case I want to know it will stay shut when its shut and open when open Well it appears to lock open ok but it wont lock closed The blade just falls open right away after you fold it up I tightened the screw to make it tougher to open and that helped a bit but it still looks like it could jostle open an inch An inch of open blade is still too much open blade when I WANT IT CLOSED The last thing I want to do when Im out in the wilderness is reach in my pack for my saw and encounter the teeth BEWARE The saw does not even fold up decently The only reason Im giving it 2 stars is because it looks like it would cut ok Buy at your own risk I thought Id enjoy having a nice lightweight yet durable fold up saw but I might just go for a normal camping saw with a blade guard Im really disappointed I wasted the money on something that looked to be a really good buy Sadly its not even worth the hassle of returning 
We have a large rectangular tent with a loop in each roof corner We have been using this one next to the entrance for 3 years now about 60 days total It has been incredibly handy for storing stuff up off the floor at eye level without taking up any real space you cannot really walk into the corners of a tent and it hangs above sleeping level I have a 20 off code and decided to get three more for the remaining corners It did get bent out of shape once but I just kept it pressed between 2 boards during storage and it is as good as new again We have not had a tear yet and we have put over 5 lbs of stuff in it Since the mesh extends about 34 of the way around there is not much worry about stuff falling out Since it fold flat it travels very well

I bought this for my stepdad as a gift So I havent actually used it It does appear however to be of the same quality as the two burner Coleman I do own This 1burner model is well made Its definitely designed in a way that could accept either a small coffee pot or other camping pot all the way up to a nice sized cast iron skillet or a huge regular sized pot of water usually used for boiling spaghetti or the like I went with this product because of its stability I love the low profile and wide base It will really give a nice pot of chili the stability you need when cooking and stirring The other models that screw directly onto the burner seemed like theyd be top heavy or would need a really level surface to be able to relax a little while cooking Its got a good weight to it  durable enough to know itll support what youre cooking but not so heavy that its going to be a pain in the ass to take places This is the perfect burner for the weekend camper the car camper the occasional camperbasically any camper thats not going on a 5 day backpacking excursion Its also a good just in case burner in case you lose electricity or need something in an emergency situation I also like that it attaches to the smaller gas tanks that are cheap and convenient to pack and carry It may not be absolutely wind resistant but its low profile gives someone with a little ingenuity plenty of options to fashion up some sort of wind barrier if it comes to that I havent actually used this yet but like I said it looks and feels a lot like my two burner Coleman and that one has worked flawlessly for years without any issues whatsoever It even has the same gas attachment as my other Coleman so it looks like they just took things and reconfigured for a single burner model I really cant foresee this model acting up but I will update as I have a chance to For the price I couldnt pass this up Great value I only gave it 4 stars because I havent actually used it yet So that rating is based on my initial observations and my past experience with Coleman burners While I dont own any 141 oz tanks I imagine those would work just fine The 169 oz are the commonly featured tank and I know those fit perfectly with this stove I believe the bushingsthreads are the same on the 141 oz tanks I also know they sell 141169 ozto20 lb tank adapters so that you can hook this puppy up to a 20 lb tank So because the adapter is named with both weights on it Id assume both would fit this stove Those are just my observations on the 141 oz tank though

As usual Coleman makes the best camping products Having said that I didnt order it for camping I love the Brazilian Churrascaria restaurants with thier fresh grilled variety of meats so my wife bought a miniature Churrascaria meat grilling setup through the Home Shopping Network for home use But the unit she bought is designed to fit down over an indoor GAS stove burner when you remove the pot  pan stand Our range is electric Most of the other portable oneburner gas stoves have permanently mounted pot  pan stands or when you remove the ones that dont the burner doesnt protrude from the stove like a normal inhome gas range burner would In the case of this coleman singleburner stove the burner protrudes like on a home stove and the grate easily pops out One last benefit that I hadnt counted on is the fact that the base plate is EXACTLY the same width as the Churrascaria grill setup In fact when placed on top of the burner it looks like the two units are made for each other Thats how good the fit is So if you like the idea of grilling meats on a skewer indoors but dont have a gas stove the Churrascaria grill sold on HSN fits like a glove on this particular portable singleburner gas stove 
I have used this stove for both car camping and cooking at bike races and like a few things about it One is that it is much more stable than the typical single burner stoves so putting a large pot or pan on the grates is not a problem In addition the propane gas cylinders are quite cheap in comparison to the jetboils or other small tank stoves so it is cheaper to operate On the other hand there are a few easy fixes that would make this a better product One is that the unit requires a small extension tube to connect to the fuel tank and this needs to be unscrewed and carried separately The bottom of the stove has lots of room but that is taken up by a rather useless piece of aluminum that could easily have been modified to allow the tank connector to snap into place so it is not lost in moving the unit around Organization is particular important for camping as you have lots of stuff and if one of the parts is missing it means the unit is worthless In addition the aluminum piece on the bottom is razor sharp so while cleaning it this evening I brushed my thumb on the edge of the guard and had a nasty cut These kinds of things are so obvious that I just dont understand how a company with as much experience as Coleman could miss them

After several seasons with a Sport Brella Ive concluded umbrellas dont work at the beach because its only a matter of time before the right gust uproots the Umbrella Ive tried a number of anchoring methods all with the same result I see only Pros and no Cons with the Coleman Road Trip Beach shade There are some practical Considerations Pros especially vs Any Umbrella 1 Unidirectional full shade for 2 in Beach Chairs 2 Front Porch flap lets you leave sand and damp towels outside your sitting area 3 Rear door enables ample circulation and eliminates gustcapsizing 4 Full zipup offers full privacy or some security when you go in the water or head for snacks 5 360 degree protection from a rain or windstorm 6 It CANT blow away since you and your gear are weighing it down 7 Oh and it has a FLOOR you have the option of sitting or setting things anywhere 8 Pockets at all 4 corners for sunglasses snacks keys whatever 9 Less than half the pack size  weight yet more than twice the functionality of any Umbrella 10 No center pole Wide open spaces Considerations 1 Takes longer to set up and pack up but the benefits are definitely worth it 2 If youre at a crowded beach youll block the ocean view of those behind you Oh well Thats about it It would be very unwise to choose an umbrella over this product and this shelter leads its category for value

I already have both the 2burner rectangular stoves with lid  windscreen and also the burneronbottle product both from Coleman This single burner filled my need for something that packs much smaller than the 2burner is way safer than the burneronbottle and can share a 30x30in dining table I just used it today for a minipicnic cooking hamburgers at the table and it suddenly occured that duh its very sociable to cook right in front of your guests That would not have happened with the other stoves because of size and risks I skimmed the other reviews and yes the diameter is larger than expected verging on a disappointment since I was trying to pack smaller for small car camping I found the smooth continuous flame adjustment to be a much welcome improvement over the notchy adjustment of the burneronbottle product from coleman Im missing piezo electric start but a butane wand was a competent substitute 
I have some nephews starting into boy scouts and was interested in a stove they might like I liked the idea of one like this versus ones that sit on disposable tanks since it looks more stable as well as being able to connect it to a bulk tank if wanted with a hose Looking at the online pictures I liked the way this one looked with round bars for the pot support versus bent sheet metal supports in similar ones and thought That looks better if someone did try to carry such in a backpack since it wont have knifeblade like edges easily ripping into things So I ordered one up even with seeing some reviews of This is bigger than I expected thinking it may be 810 inches across versus 68 and not seeing anyone giving dims on it The truth is that the main body is 12 inch diameter at the base it is almost 14 inches across at the feet the widest points and the pot support bars will hold an 11 inch diameter pot with it sitting flat on the horizontal parts of the bars So maybe that tells you more about how Big it really is versus pictures of it alone that are hard to scale with no comparisons This also explains to me why it goes for over 30 versus many single burner stoves going for 1520 that I wondered about too before ordering it Ill keep it since having this may be as good or better than many 2 burner stoves where putting a 11 inch pan on them ends up with almost 12 the pan hanging off the edges but I hope this helps minimize surprises for others of you considering this

Picked this up for metal detecting Some of the ground in the area is hard so I thought a shovelpick combo would be great I wanted it to be small and packable this definitely fits the bill I dug 4 holes about 8 in diameter approximately 5 deep in my back yard and on the fourth hole the shovel blade bent It bent like a spoon in hard cold ice cream Clean in the middle of the blade close to 90 degrees I bent it back but once its been compromised its a lost cause My back yard is sod and the dirt is slightly clay like its not dry or hard but very slightly on the heavy side I was in complete disbelief when it bent and flat out angry when I saw just how bad it was with as little power as I had applied The locking ring also did not hold the shovel head solidly from the beginning It never had a positive lock The pick does hold firm but not the shovel After the second hole I dug the shovel head would not stay in position at all and I had to keep forward pressure on it so it wouldnt fold while pushing it into the ground The steel used is very low quality It doesnt matter if you harden it like they state in the description because low quality steel just wont get hard enough as is the case with the low carbon junk steel used here I could have done better using a decent hard wood stick to dig the holes and that is absolutely not an exaggeration Lasted 3 and a half small holes in not so tough ground About 3 minutes of total use Steer clear folks this one is garbage

This is your basic single burner propane outdoor stove It works with 1 lb propane bottles for portability and with an adapter hose can be connected to a 20 lb propane tank I use one of these regularly and enjoy using it If you get one here are a couple of tips 1 Get a Stove Tamernbspa datahookproductlinklinked classalinknormal hrefStoveTamer6dpB000I1X3TGrefcmcrarpdrvwtxtieUTF8Stove Tamer 6a so that you can use smaller pots tin cups etc or to simply have better control over the heat It will allow you to get a better low temp simmer without worrying about the stove blowing out 2 The pot rack will pull free from the plasitc legs allowing you to give the stove a good cleaning without working around the rack Once its dissasembled in this manner you can throw it in the sink and wash it like you would any other pan I used one of these on the patio all summer for making coffee in the morning and side dishes when grilling out I did not have any problems Prior to purchasing this stove I used a Coleman FoldNGo Since I never needed two burners on the patio I packed the two burner stove with the camping gear and use this guy exclusively

This lamp is wonderful It cranks out the light just like the ancient one my father had while I was growing up when we went camping The only problem is the way Coleman designed the case the lamp is protected in The way the case closes at the base makes it extremely vulnerable to opening up on you and the lamp sliding out while carrying it as described by previous reviewers In my opinion the flaws in the case design should not keep you from ordering the lamp and case set I use a strip of duck tape across the bottom or a small Bungie Cord looped to the handle to hold the base on securely Hopefully Coleman will check these reviews and redesign the case closure to alleviate the problem of unexpected opening The lamp is traditional Coleman Quality and worth the purchase I recommend this lamp and case set

This is the best bang for your buck if you want a new GPA lantern It is fuel efficient and there is no noticeable difference in light output between this and the powerhouse I have both and have run them side by side The Northstar is a brighter lantern but you could buy 2 of these for the price of one of those Notice that I am ignoring the propane models I find them to be wasteful on fuel and their cold weather performance is lacking The only downside is they dont sell these in green paint anymore This is my go to lantern for camping and emergencies I recommend trying some peerless mantles with this lantern They appear to be as bright or brighter than the colemans and more durable 
This item arrived promptly from amazon Thought I would share that it does come with filtered funnel even though it was not in description The only down side to this whole package was the case If is ok and does the job but kinda flimsy and funnel is very difficult to fit in case but can be done For just over 50 and free shipping price is right and like that you can use unleaded gasoline or coleman fuel I have an coleman fuel Green later but thought it would be nice to keep it as a back up and use this to save cost and not carry extra fuel for an atv outing I recommend this over propane because easier to carry a small container of unleaded gasoline in a pack that propane bottles and cheaper Hope this review helps 
Very intense white light I cant offer much more than other reviewers except a couple of learning curve issues I had First take out the plungerprimer stem before first use then reinsert it I found that mine had an air pocket in it that would not let me prime it properly I got some fuel primed but it just didnt seem bright Once air pocket cleared and properly primed I noticed the hiss was much louder and the light was very intense Secondly I find that Crown fuel from the big box store burns brighter than gasoline It is also half the cost of what the Coleman fuel is Plus if you spill some it doesnt smell nearly as bad or as long as gasoline Awesome lantern that you can pass down for generations Did I mention it has a very intense white light This will certainly light up your camp

This is a good little tool to take along with you on hikingbackpacking trips or to dig a SMALL trench around your tent if camping in order to redivert rain water It also comes with its own carrying pouch that easily slips onto any style belt I suggest matching the belt size to the belt loop of the carrying pouch otherwise this tool will dangle about and flop around while walking I bought mine a Cabelas so I paid a little extra for it This tool is also good to keep inside your car especially during winter If you get stuck on an icy road this tool will chip the ice quite nicely Ive read some of the reviews stating that this tool is heavy doesnt stay connected or they hurt themselves with it True this tool does weigh little more than the advertized pound thats because it is made out of steel and steel tends to be heavy This tool when everything is screwed together tightly does loosen itself over continued use it wasnt designed to go prospecting for gold digging a grave or such You might actually have to stop what you are doing and periodically retighten the connections Read another review that someone hurt them selves with this item well good for you dumb a He was most likely utilizing this item in an unsafe manner Overall this little shovel will do what you need it to do provided that you are safety concious Mine works just fine for digging the emergency poo parlors while hikingbackpacking Believe it or not that is what this little tools intended purpose was The only complaint that I actulally have with this tool is that its carrying pouch ripped quite easily but that was most likely my fault for I was crawling through a narrow tunnel while caving and forgot about having this tool on my tool belt and it got caught on some rocks

I grew up around this lantern while camping and wanted one of my own for a very long time It burns very bright with an easily adjustable dimmer If you want a real camping experience ditch the LED lanterns and pick this baby up It comes with two mantels that are easy to tie on and prime I dont see any problems with the build quality of these later coleman lanterns The pump does have some plastic parts but oil it once a year and dont put crappy fuel gasoline kerosene in it and itll last forever Yes it is a little noisy slight hissing sound not a big deal and yes it gets very hot Its a lantern for cryin out loud Dont touch it dont put it in your tent and dont leave it burning in some grass However do let your kids touch it once and then youll never have to worry about it again Thats what my dad did and I learned my lesson quick 55 stars cause its be best lantern youll ever buy 
I burn I burn very very easily My wife goes outside for five minutes and gets a fantastic tan Im a little bitter about that but hey we all have our shortcomings Mine is that I crisp instead of tan Our new apartment is about a 15 minute walk to the beach and with her being from Virginia Beach she loves the water I decided to search around and find something that might spare me the agony of sitting on the beach for more than five minutes and I found this Why the green color is cheaper than the others is beyond me but a slight discount is a slight discount so I went for it Maybe theres better colors out there but given the sea of lime green beach shades Ive seen so far at the beach Id say were all cheap and want to save what we can The design is a bit tricky for me Ive put together various tents my whole life and this one is a bit of a challenge Personally I think the fabric tube for the crosstube that goes longways across the shade is much to narrow and it makes it tricky to get the pole to successfully stay in one piece while youre trying to set up the shade Im sure the more I use this the more Ill figure out its quirks but I wasnt particularly pleased spending a massive amount of time putting this small thing together and ripping some of the mesh tube when Ive put an 8 person tent together in what seemed like a much shorter amount of time The quality of the shade other than the narrow pole tubes is great We spent several hours in the shade and it was very comfortable The attached flooring is a nice touch though sand will get everywhere and if youre wet from the water when you sit down itll pool and sand will stick I think next time well place towels down first The stakes were great quality and Im thrilled they were metal instead of plastic The included bags to store everything were also wellmade and with some patience aka giving my wife the tent and bag the whole thing did end up fitting back into the storage tote I will mention that even with the window in the back and the entrance to the tent being open it does get pretty warm in there It wasnt unbearable but I did end up ordering two small batteryoperated fans anyway to help circulate some air Im sure the majority of people wont need to do that but if youre like me and you sweat and become very warm easily then you may want to invest in some cheap fans Im super happy with this so far and it has absolutely made my trips to the beach much more fun and much less painful so for that Im very grateful 
Im glad we got this one Its wellmade and designed but the mesh sleeves for the poles should be solid The curved mesh catches on the metal ferrules and separates the links Weve been using cabanas for almost 20 years and love it This is the biggest and 6 too big for the beach we are headed to in height and width Beach police beware If its too high I will scoop 6 of sand out below it A TRICK for setting it up solo  take at least 3 medium rubber bands along When you get the rod through band the rod to the tab with the grommet on it so it wont pop out as soon as you turn your back to work on the other end SO much easier I struggled in the living room on the test run before I remembered this The dogs simulated the wind and other problems on the beach And Im so glad they didnt send the one with the big lantern printed on the sides That seemed a bit much For all those who dont like the mesh sleeves  you could cut a long strip of nylon fabric the length of the pole sleeves and sew it into a tube  which would go inside the mesh sleeves You may need to sew it to the ends of the sleeve maybe more than that A pain  but it would eliminate the mesh problem A small rubber ball stuck on the fwd end of the pole may help too but the problem is when the ferrules catch and the segments separate AFTER using the tent and seeing how wrong the mesh sleeves are for the poles to go thru I went to Lowes and got 5 of 12OD plastic waterline not pvc And I glued a cap on one end Now I start the tube in the sleeve then push it the rest of the way through with the pole Then pull the tube out the other end This will save the mesh But really  dont they make designers try these things out The mesh will quickly puncture with the poles as designed The tent was nice with no problems you might want to put the filled sand bags in ziplock bags They dont hold sand that well The carrying bag was well made and the tent fit back in But what would it cost them to add an inch of material to make it easier Another tip  a strip of plastic or cardboard for when you zip the bag up This will stop the zipper from grabbing the tent as you need one hand to pinch the sides together and one to zip

MUST HAVE FOR A TENT 
1 After taking it all of the way to Florida for our vacation upon opening the product one of the black tent poles was defective One of the two black poles was missing a metal ferrule in the middle of the pole assemble meaning the pole did not lock together I guess i should have checked before taking it all of the way to Florida but I did not because you know  it always takes up a bit more space after repacking 2 After going through the warranty process Coleman sent a Tent Pole Replacement Kit This kit was several other fiberglass poles an elastic cord end tips and ferrules SOME ASSEMBLY REQUIRED and I had to make my own replacement pole with the kit I had to cut the poles to the correct size with a hacksaw thread the elastic cord and add the end caps myself 3 The replacement poles are thicker than the original and as a result the assembled pole is more rigid than the other black pole meaning the assembled shade is now lopsided 4 The four replacement pole segments when folded for storage are too long to be stored in the carrying case Even though the total length of the pole when assembled is the correct length Originally there were five pole segments and the replacement kit has four NOT happy

I should preface this review though by saying that the lantern I received was defective It wouldnt dim Anything other than full power brightness and the lantern would slowly fade out until it was extinguished Instead of going through Amazon I decided to contact Coleman to see if I could get replacement parts Im pretty handy so Id rather just fix it After explaining to them the issue they opted just to replace the lantern outright 100 for free under warranty Excellent customer service and it saves me the hassle of having to fix the old one I purchased this lantern for a long car camping trip from the west coast to the east coast Weve used it 3 times in the last month or so This thing is built like a tank Very robust quite heavy and works very well I couldnt imagine anyone needing the PowerHouse model as this standard model is PLENTY bright enough My only complaint is that the older design that includes a generator cleaner knob is absent from this modern design I suppose it makes it simpler to use but it loses a facet of long term reliability in my opinion Even still I cannot recommend this lantern enough Its excellent

Very thin material and so cheaply made of thin metal material that you can merely fling your finger on any piece to hear a fair tong tone The rims of each piece are hollow underneath and its true that the enamel paint is not sprayed on well as other reviewers have pointed out its not uniform at all However this is a good set if you really just need some dishes for camping that are enamel painted for nostalgia but dont necessarily care that it lasts year after year the dishes themselves may as I could see myself playing frisbee with the plates but the paint coating will probably come off within a couple uses The silverware handles are cheap plastic although surprisingly have a bit of weight to them and have silver knots in them for looks although it feels just like fake plastic painted as silver to me Bottom line take it as you will as these are very thin pieces of metal cheaply bent into nostalgic shapes and spray painted an enamel glaze while still bearing a surprisingly fair amount of weight for what they are yet all at a reasonable price 
This stoneware set is outstanding The set is exactly what is advertised it has 4 heavy duty stoneware plates that are as pictured in the bright red color not like your run of the mill every day blue or black that everyone else has so this set stands out nicely It also comes with 4 coffee cups and 4 bowls which are also the beautiful bright red stoneware color This set is awesome at least to me I immediately pulled this out of the box when it arrived and it did not disappoint at all The set also comes with all your silverware 4 knives 4 forks and 4 spoons all in a nice little pouch that rolls up and stows away in your canteen box very nicely I have already used the set a couple of times and they are as durable as camping gear comes and are exactly what you would expect from any and all Coleman products that you would buy I am definitely looking forward to the many many years of great use that I am going to get out of this complete stoneware camping set for sure 
We have a family of 4 so this set was perfect for us on our national park camping trips We didnt want to keep wasting paper and plastic products I would give this a 5 star rating but the plates and some cups came chipped with the enamel already wearing off We contacted amazon and they sent a replacement fast The replacement arrived today and the same issue on some of the plates and bowls this time The plates this time also came with a thick drip like gobs on the tops of 2 plates They stick up about a quarter of an inch and run about 4 inches around on the plates Im thinking these are just going to be something that will always have an issue and over time need to be replaced Our last set was many years old the enamel wore off after years of use and being banged around eventually started to rust Thats my concern with these ones and why I wanted them replaced right away The silverware in this set is wonderful though They come with a carry case for them and each have their own place in that case The knives were great and even cut through grilled steaks with ease very impressed for what seemed like a butter knive I have to say though for coleman I was not too impressed with their quality it seems to be lacking from what I remember about the brand I was shocked to turn over each plate bowl and cup and see a sticker that said China ok the back I had assumed that coleman was still a product made in the USA I was sadly mistaken I looked up coleman to see what had happened to the quality of the products and this is what I believe has happened The Coleman Companys headquarters are in Wichita and it also has facilities in Texas There are approximately 3600 employees but most are not manufacturing jobs1 The majority of their goods are now manufactured in China  This came from wikipedia

I also have the older model of this The key feature I like on this new one is the ability to adjust the output I havent yet decided whether to buy the new one for the adjustment feature as the old one works great But I am about to set out on a 30 day winter camping trip and the ability to run it at a much lower rate is tempting We originally got the old one to use in a boat for winter overnights in our MacGregor 26X It was so WONDERFUL It took a wouldbe miserable situation of being cold and dark in early evening at anchor and wanting to play a game rather than trying to read or sleep through a bunch more winter hours This warmed the cabin of our little sailboat up in about 20 mins to where you could take off mittens to hold cards We would then let the heater run for about an hour get it fairly toasty then turn it off and head off to bed and reading in the sleeping bag only after it got to cold to hold cards again If I didnt aready have an older model that works perfectly I would buy one of these instantly And guys if you want your gals to do more camping and be happier doing it get her one of these 
I have the older version of this heater without the auto lighting feature Ive used this heater for about five years and cant say anything bad about it Originally I bought it for tent camping in a small tent During a cool rainy spell we stayed in the tent and were as snug as a bug in a rug We being myself and my cocker spaniel I then went up to a popup camper and used it there as well and was pleased with the heat it put out for such a small heater This winter Ive been using it in my small computer room and it has really warmed up the area if I keep the door closed except for about 6 inches I would recommend this heater to anyone Dont expect it to heat a large room or large tent But for the price and the operating cost you cant beat it I also recently ordered an adapter that allows you to refill the 1 lb bottles from a 20 lb tank You cant refill them indefinitely but 34 times which will save a bunch of money and you put less of these bottles into the landfill If there was a 10star rating I would give this a 10 
I took this heater camping in Delaware on Columbus Day weekend October I used it in a wellventilated 4person mediumsized tent The first 2 days were cold and rainy and I was VERY glad to have brought it Now this heater is not going to make your tent into a sauna on a very cold day so dont expect to get in the tent and lounge in your skivies like you might do at home But after burning for about 1015 min it should raise the temperature in your tent several precious degrees making it bareable even comfortable For instance it did keep me from having to wear my heavy coat while inside the tent which pleased me Since it would certainly heat a smaller lessvented tent better than a larger morevented tent your results may vary As for me the results were not dramatic but certainly noticable and well worth the money spent Note This kind of catalytic heater requires those mini propane tanks It works by a chemical reaction between a meshy platinum filter and the burning propane gas so while theres no obvious propane smell and no open flame theres still a very hot surface that could catch objects on fire if they are placed directly in front of it for too long FYI when you first light it you may indeed see an igniting flame but that is just upon start up Once the starting flame vanishes put your hand gently over the heater  if you feel it eminating warmth youll know youve started it successfully Warning Just as the instructions warn you I do NOT recommend leaving this heater on through the night when you and your family are asleep It is both a breathing hazard and an obvious fire hazard But warning stated I did just that and I didnt have a problem I slept very comfortably on a couple cold nights and I didnt die in my sleep Again your results may vary However I should note that my own tent is extreamly well ventilated with the entire ceiling being mesh under the rain fly In addition the night was windy and I could actually feel a breeze of air circulating in my tent In truth if I had brought a lessventilated coldweather tent with me that weekend the heater may not have been needed at night but since I was stuck with a drafty tent I took the calculated risk that this would also lessen the threat In addition I took every possible precaution to ensure that nothing was near the heater before going to sleep Even so its a risk that I could not blame anyone for not wanting to take Also if you do this expect the propane tank to be empty by morning All in all other than the obvious handlewithcare factors I could not find a downside to this product In fact I could not imagine coldweather camping without it PS They also sell a slightly cheaper version which is the same in every way except it does not have the selfstarting switch and you start it manually with a lit match 
Like a lot of people on here have said its pretty easy to put together The kids love it

Weve recently converted a van for camping and built in lengthwise combination bench seatsbeds in the backthe listed size of these was perfect for them and the specspricing attractive so in spite of reading some negative reviews we decided to give them a try We did as the instructions said and let them fluff for over 30 hours before the triphmmm not nearly up to the 25 claimed so we put them in the van and made the 8 hour drive to our first campsitestill not close to the advertised thickness so we added lots air by mouth put them on top of our old thermarests for extra padding and headed to bed The mats quickly proved impossible to stay onthe fabric is so slick that not only did the sleeping bags quickly slide off but the mats also slid off the extra pads we had underneathfortunately  the mats started loosing air quickly and as they did they stayed in place betterstrange to think of a mat loosing air as a benefit but it was  These were a focusconstant concern during the 5 nights we camped and were returned quickly and easilythank you Amazon on our return Its too bad they didnt workguess well have to bite the bullet and go back to the higher priced and reliable matts 
I enjoy my pad I use it in conjunction with a thermorest closed cell pad Im a backpacker and haul all of this in too I use both for the combined comfort and most importantly the R value Most of my backpacking is done in the winter months so I prefer all of the insulation I can get If you use an external frame pack lashing all of this on isnt a problem Just remember if it hasnt been used in some time to allow it to inflate for 24hrs before your trip A few puffs of air after self inflation does well also just a few do not over inflate For the price ya cant beat it

Great little set to grab and go for my husband and our 2 cub scouts 
First of all the price listed here is incorrect These retail at most sporting goods stores for between 80100 The optional piezoelectric starter is not needed if you simply keep a lighter handy Ive used one of these while motorcycle camping for a couple years and it really works well It produces enough heat to raise the temperature of my 3season 4man tent about 25 degrees when it dips below 30 outside even with two screen walls That makes the difference between being really comfy and sleeping well or being restless and waking throughout the night The heater will operate at full power for 10 hours on one propane cartridge Ive run it that long so you dont have to worry about it running out of fuel at 400 AM It operates silently but the heating surface does get very hot It will instantly meltchar nylon or other fabrics so you have to very carefully place this thing away from tent walls sleeping bags inflatables pets and clothes It also needs good ventilation as it consumes a lot of oxygen Respect it and be smart and youll be safe and warm all night Coleman understandably recommends not sleeping with it operating but thats why we buy these things I highly recommend that you test run it for a couple hours before using it in an enclosed space When new it can produce a disagreeable odor kinda like burnt metal and paint After being broken in  its fine The plastic body which surrounds the heater is bulky The earlier version of this with a simple wire prop stand was much more compact Still if you have the space its a great investment Its said tents keep you dry  sleeping bags keep you warm which is true but a little gem like this will put a smile on your face when the temperature drops below 40 degrees 
Perfect for warming up in the deer blind or for those cold spring and fall camping nights 
Been using it for a couple of years now and works good Puts out decent amount of heat for Colorado nights There are several issues with this product Lighting can be a bit unclear when it is actually lit pending on the lighting conditions to be able to see the mesh faintly glow indicating it is lit But it does light fairly easy and convenient with the builtin switch One of the legs fractured a bit from rotating it  although some user error to blame there wish it was more durable it still stands up ok though This product does NOT have tip over protection where it will shut off upon tipping over Although it has legs and a tripod stance it could tip over pretty easily on a tent floor on rough ground or just being knocked from accidental impact There is no low oxygen sensor or shut off protection from low oxygen The Coleman website specifically states to use in well ventilated area and do not use while sleeping Im assuming for several safety reasons including possibility of tipping it over But I bought this item to use at night while camping since that is when it gets cold mostly I would recommend looking at the Mr Heater one as well for around the same price which looks sturdier and has safety features builtin and is approved for indoor use httpwwwamazoncomMrHeaterF2151003800BTUIndoorSafedpB001CFRF7Irefsr12ieUTF8qid1407387059sr82keywordsmrheater httpwwwamazoncomMrHeaterF232000IndoorSafePortabledpB002G51BZUrefsr11shomegardenieUTF8qid1406819767sr11keywordsmrheaterbuddyportableheater As far as other safety issues there are concerns of carbon monoxide poisoning with any device like this but rvroadtrips websitie explains the safety an risks involved with catalytic heaters Which from what I have read catalytic heaters do not burn with an open flame and this reduces the amount of carbon monoxide and other toxic fumes emitted compared to an open flame heater BUT it is NOT the existence of carbon monoxide or toxic fumes which is the danger when using a heater like this indoors it is the potential for the LACK of oxygen since this also consumes oxygen So still having a well ventilated space to allow for oxygen to flow into your space is still a must safety info here httprvroadtripsthefuntimesguidecom201202catalyticheatersphp

First I should probably note that the version of this pad that I bought at a brickandmortar store is labeled Coleman Max so it may not be exactly the same thing  but it looks pretty much the same Its the same color as the darker one in the closeup of the valve and the valve is identical I actually paid about ten dollars less than Amazons posted price at the time of this review Im a bony guy and really wanted something with a little more loft than my Thermarest SOLite pad which is a little on the large side when rolled anyway even though I bought the short version for bike camping trips It had to be reasonably light and packable and I figured Id give this a shot since I could return it if it didnt work My expectations I admit were not actually very high Ive been disappointed by many sleeping pads in the past and would actually have just purchased one of those small floatationdevice style air mattresses if my hubby had not firmly suggested that one of these might offer better insulation and so forth I was willing to give it a try but still worried that my boniness and sidesleeping tendencies could be problematic In practice this pad significantly exceeded my expectations That said theres a bit of a process involved in getting it to work right A PreInflate As the manufacturer suggests before your first camping trip unroll it open the valve and let it sit for as long as possible  twentyfour hours if you can I bought mine the day before my trip so I had to make due with sixish Then deflate it roll it close the valve and pack it B Dont Wait Til Youre Ready for Bed When you make camp set your tent up unroll your pad open the valve immediately and let it do its thing Of note we rolled into camp on our second night only a couple hours before bed I set up my tent and pad right away and it was fine C Give It An Assist Perhaps most importantly  give the pad several good puffs by mouth this by the way has been recommended for every single selfinflating pad Ive considered  including much more expensive models  The style of the valve makes this a bit challenging but youll get the hang of it quickly Youll want to give it a little more air than you think you need because it will lose a little as youre screwing the valve shut Some users find the tufted design of this pad uncomfortable I on the other hand feel that the tufted design is exactly what makes it so very comfortable for someone like me Where a nontufted pad might be compressed flat at my bony points the tufted billows in this pad offer support and relief On its first night out I shoved it into my sleeping bag and slept better than I sleep at home Thats not hyperbole by the way  I really mean it I slept better than I normally do at home even after a comparablychallenging day on the bike There are pads in the world that pack smaller and there are probably better pads  and if I were backpacking instead of traveling by bicycle I might want one of those However for less than fifty bucks a little finagling makes this pad work just fine Pros Tufted design works well for bony people Holds air once inflated Deflates easily and packs reasonably small for the price Builtin compression straps are great For its price point offers exceptional comfort Attached pillow can be inflated by mouth or left uninflated Your choice Cons Some users dont enjoy the tufted design Not entirely selfinflating Inflates a tad slowly Not ideal for backpackers doesnt pack small enough

Unit seems to work very well I had the 1000 BTU version before and that model just didnt put out enough heat other than to warm your hands Granted we were camping in 9 degree weather This 3000 BTU unit puts out a very noticeable amount of heat I have yet to try it again in 9 degree weather but we used it outside one cold night sitting around a table just to see how well it worked and 4 of us noticed the heat I think this unit will work extremely well inside a tent While supposedly safe in a tent I am still a little nervous about carbon monoxide I tested the unit inside my house with a home CO detector sitting a foot away I left it running for 2030 mins and the alarm never went off That reassured me a bit I think we may make a habit of taking the detector with us when we plan to use this inside a tent Better safe than sorry  The only thing that kept me from giving it a fifth star was the electronic ignition was kinda hit and miss I would recommend always having matches or a lighter as a backup but thats just smart to do anyway when youre camping

Upsides It works Downsides The InstaStart thingy doesnt No matter how many times I press the button I see the little spark but apparently not enough propane is in the vicinity of that spark to fire it off I use a longsnout butane barbecue lighter to light the thing without being barbecued Its not very adjustable Theres low heat Theres high heat Thats it The metal grill on the front gets very hot You must be very careful where you place this thing so that said grill doesnt contact you your tent your dog your upholstery in the small van youre trying to heat up or anything else flammable Youd think they could at least put some sort of flared guard or bumpers around the front to help keep stuff from coming in contact with that metal grill sort of like the bumpers on chicken house heaters to keep their metal grill from contacting stuff if the heater is knocked over but apparently thatd require too much thought Theres only one safe way to place this heater  on its side with the legs extended as shown in the product photo You cant stand it up like a candle it might fall over and then that metal ring around the front which gets very hot would contact something that you probably dont want contacted This doesnt put out much heat on high heat but still drains a 1 pound can of propane within four hours No problem you say youll just hook it up to the 20 pound tank for your barbecue and have plenty of heat for all night camping for a week Uhm no a there is no way to hook a 20 pound tank to this heater and b if you did rig up a hose of some sort see the part about only one safe way to place this heater  by removing the rear leg the 1 pound canister the heater is now in an attitude that is unsafe Coleman says dont do it and theyre right  this heater simply is designed wrong to be safe when used with an external propane tank Theres no safety cutoff to turn off the heater if it gets bumped and falls over from the pictured attitude which as I noted is the only safe attitude So dont leave the heater alone with a dog or large cat that might bump into it and make it fall over or you might come back to a smoldering tent and barbecued FidoFluffy All in all this heater works but its profoundly mediocre Ive used it in my garage to supplement an electric heater that struggles with cooler temperatures but due to its limitations never used it for camping as originally intended and probably wont ever do so In particular the very hot grill on the front is such a safety hazard that I refuse to use it anywhere but on the concrete floor of my garage where if it falls over all thatll happen is that it contacts nonflammable concrete Im now researching better options for a tent heater because this just isnt acceptable to me Youd have to haul along a metal roasting pan and a piece of fiberglass insulation to make this safe to use in a tent the pan to hold the heater the fiberglass insulator to go under the pan to insulate it from the tent floor and at that point youre into a realm of clunkiness that makes me say eh time to do something else

I grew up with Coleman pressure lanterns as the child of missionaries in the South Pacific 3rd World For years Coleman pressure lanterns and a few hurricane lanterns lit our nights on the other side of the world These days as outdoor lovers  and prepping for emergency power outages short or longterm  we decided to add a couple of these lanterns to our equipment We love the fact that theres been a breakthrough in fuel supply These also readily burn regular car gasoline and that makes them extra useful and certainly worth a few more bucks What you save on gasoline by the gallon alone is worth the money yesterday the price of a gallon of white gas at my hardware store was 13 In general with all our equipment we burn gasoline that is treated withnbspa datahookproductlinklinked classalinknormal hrefSeaFoamSF16MotorTreatment16ozdpB0002JN2EUrefcmcrarpdrvwtxtieUTF8Sea Foam SF16 Motor Treatment  16 oza This is so much better than the competitors gasoline treatmentforstorage products and keeps all your gasoline engines starting and running better It came to us recommended by a highly experienced small engine mechanic and our engine headaches largely disappeared after that We use it regularly in all our equipment truck and car Treated gas burns great in this lantern and I can even leave fuel in the tank ready to go in an emergency We bought this with another great blast from the past  thenbspa datahookproductlinklinked classalinknormal hrefColemanGuideSeriesPowerhouseTMDualFuelTMStovedpB00006I56JrefcmcrarpdrvwtxtieUTF8Coleman Guide Series PowerhouseTM Dual FuelTM Stovea Its another classic now improved by being able to burn gasoline as well This lanterns comes in a strong hard shell which makes taking it camping extraeasy You dont want to break the glass or shatter the mantles We have seen the light Strongly Recommended

This is a review from a hunters perspective and rates the performance of the Coleman BlackCat EI Catalytic Heater heater according to the environment it is used in Why I purchased the heater  To use in my Primos Ground Max Eclipse Hunting Blind httpwwwamazoncomPrimosGB2500TheEclipseBlinddpB001P5G6TI which has the dimensions L x W x H 770 x 770 x 700 while deer hunting  Because I do not have adequate cold weather footwear I should buy some and my toes get too cold very easily  I hunt in Texas where the wind is always blowing and because so it can chill you quiet quickly even with our mildly cold winter weather  To have a portable heater for tailgating events and to play my guitar on my back porch in the winter wout freezing How stereotypically hick of me  How I used it in context to this review  I used it in my Primos Ground Max Eclipse Hunting Blind httpwwwamazoncomPrimosGB2500TheEclipseBlinddpB001P5G6TI which has the dimensions L x W x H 770 x 770 x 700 while hunting deer Pros  Heats well for the reasons I bought it I keep it right at my feet and it heats up my feet and legs warm which in turn keeps me warm all over Does not keep the hunting blind warmed up as I have the hunting windows open preventing any real heat build up in the blind  It is very simple to operate You turn the knob to high for about 3045 seconds so propane will feed out and then you press the electric striker to fire up the heater I have seen other portable propane heaters that need a match or that force you to prime the device for 1 minute then you strike and hold the knob in a pilot light ignition position for another minute then you reset the knob and turn on to the desired heat level That is too much trouble  The heater is very quiet An animal within 5 yards will likely not hear the sound The closest encounter I have had is a deer 20 yards away and it did not hear or smell the heater Even the strike of the ignition switch is not much louder then when I bump my rifle against my chair leg or my shooting stick  Works well on high and low settings I used it on both settings in 12F temperature where everything was covered in frost and with 15 mph wind blowing from the north Had no issues keeping my feet and in turn my body warm When my fingers got a little cold I just put my hands down between my legs to catch the rising heat and they warmed up nicely Cons  Has a very slight propane burning odor on high setting It was only noticeable when I bent down to warm my hands and the heater was on high I did not really notice it when the heater was on low or when I was sitting completely erect in my chair If you are hunting you should be upwind of your prey anyway making this slight odor a nonissue  Takes 3045 seconds to start up I would stop the heater after I would warm up and then start it up again later when I was getting chilled I would become impatient waiting the 3045 seconds and click the starter a few times making noise and taking my attention away from hunting etc This is basically a me problem and could be solved by just being more patient Concluding Statement I have not used the heater in a great deal of situations so I cannot give you any information on the life durability and exact efficiency of the heater All I know is that it works well for my hunting needs and I would buy another if I needed it I also think that it would keep my feet and legs warm even in an open tripod hunting stand or a tree stand For non hunters this would work fine for direct heat in a camping or emergency situation It would not effectively heat an uninsulated space larger than the dimensions of my blind I hope this information is helpful

Just got one of these and its not all that great It is pretty bright at first but gets dim very quickly Ive used coleman lanterns for years and this is probably one of the worst as you have to keep pumping it up You get about 15 minutes of good light out of it then it starts to dim after about 25 minutes itll start flickering and after about 45 minutes itll get so dim that its unusable if you dont pump it up some more Put about 3040 pumps in it and repeat all night long It says you get 7 hours of run time on high but the adjustment range is so narrow that you dont get any more run time by turning it down on low These are nothing like the old 200A and 220 series lanterns that they used to make Also the mantles that it comes with arent very good About half the time they dont survive being burned in so make sure you have plenty of spares Peerless mantles are much better brighter and more durable if you can get them

I bought this because we were going camping while it was still pretty cold outside When you get it you need to burn it to get rid of the initial fumes It lights easily and does project a warm area in front of the unit If the air is still you can use it outside If it is windy forget about it It is still not clear if it is recommended for use inside a tent while sleeping I found conflicting information We have a large 16X8 dome tent with an open mesh top covered by a fly so I felt like it would be OK to run inside Im still alive so it didnt kill me It did warm the tent but in reality the heat is going out the top of the tent It helped keep us warm during a very cold night We actually got some sleep everyone else in our group was groggy the next day because they were so cold I woke up at 2 am with a frozen face and replaced they empty cylinder then relit it There are heaters that burn outside the tent and warm inside but they are big and expensive My wife and kids liked the comfort Is it worth the cost of the unit and a few cylinders of gas to keep you warm at night For us the answer is yes in the right situation When its cold and you have kids or a frozen wife its worth its weight in gold The quality is decent not great so I give it 4 stars

This lantern is awesome and gives the perfect type of orange glow to a camp site Ive had this lantern for a few years and used it several times there have been no problems lighting this lantern and the brightness is very adjustable from a dim glow to bright enough that it hurts to look at if your eyes are adjusted to the darkness You do need to pump it every hour or so or it will eventually go out Most negative reviews of Coleman products tend to focus on poor construction of their current products relative to the lanterns of yesteryear but this lantern is constructed perfectly fine and I expect it to last decades 
 Please Note This is a repost and reedit of a review of the dual fuel lantern WITHOUT the hard case written 10 JUN 14 and includes new information  Amazon no longer lists the lantern this review was originally for even though its the same exact lantern as the one offered here  Also please note that the lantern and case offered here costs less than the lantern alone from WalMart so this is likely the best way to go Are the lanterns sold through WalMart of a different quality from those sold through other retail outlets or is Colemans overall quality declining Hard to say which but it took SIX of these from WalMart to get three that worked after a fashion and even then had to replace the pressure valve in one tank wouldnt pressurize after only six or eight uses and the pump cup in another very stiff draggy pump action even after proper lubrication  I just got to the point where I didnt want to hassle with bringing numbers 4 and 5 back I occasionally have to use three of these in the nesting barn hung from the ceiling in a row spaced about sixteen feet apart and the difference in the amount of light each individual lantern put outs is quite apparent Using unleaded gasoline two are reasonably brightish in an orangey sort of way but still dont put out as much light as I remember the green Coleman Fuel Only lanterns producing and the light is NOT bright white but the third is only about twothirds as bright as the others no matter how I tweak it or what variables I change Ive tried all the bigname unleaded gasoline brands as well as the cheapies  10 ethanol blend which is about all they sell in and around Mount Goatmore Texas and pure gasoline when I can find it  and it doesnt seem to make much difference The dual fuel lanterns work just fine with Coleman fuel but then whats the point of paying the premium for the alleged dual fuel capability and work almost as well with a 5050 mix of Coleman Fuel and 10 ethanol unleaded gasoline which is the route Im going Their light output with the 5050 mix is still not quite bright white but it IS brighter and less orangey than using unleaded gasoline alone Ill likely have to dig down to the bottom of my camping box and see if I still have any of the lantern mantles from the 80s that were made with thorium and were BRIGHT  BRIGHT  BRIGHT and see if that helps any Things to consider 1 If youre going to store it fueled up for emergency use store it 34 filled with Coleman fuel and NOT unleaded gasoline 2 Buy the hard plastic storage case if it is not included as part of a package  worth every penny Make sure the bottom tabs are properly secured when you close the case Ive never had a problem with the case bottom coming unfastened and dropping the lantern I have these three lanterns two green Coleman Fuel lanterns and one 1975 red single mantle lantern  all in Coleman plastic cases but other reviewers have experienced this 3 A longnose disposable butane utility lighter will make lighting a snap and will store inside the hard plastic storage case 4 Two or three packs of spare mantles will store under the lantern in the hard plastic storage case

I purchased this for a trip to Glacier National Park and for other camping adventures It folds down to a very packable size The fuel container takes white gas available at all camping stores It starts easily and burns hot  both burners but particularly the primary burner There is enough stovetop space for a frying pan and a smaller kettle for sides I have owned two of these units and am happy with both My current stove has a slight problem in that the fuel container does not fit snugly in the cutouts I will need to do some bending of the inserts to get it to stay in place thus the 4star rating There are two side wind shields that help contain the heat from the burners under the grill area After each use purge the fuel container of excess pressure to make the gaskets last longer Periodically oil the plunger for years of troublefree use My last unit lasted over 25 years This one has quality improvements in the fuel container and the burners so I expect it to perform better than the last and hopefully last just as long konedog 
My green suitcase coleman is 46 years old and running like a champ If you are into disposable material goods then dont pick this stove If you want to hand it down through the family to your kids and grandkids then snag it now About fuels Coleman fuel stoves run signifigantly cheaper than propane leave no bottles to dispose of and do not have problems at high altitudes or low temps like propane models can The dualfual colemans silver tanks are nice for emergency purposes but Coleman suggests you run coleman fuel in them instead of unleaded anyhow to keep from fouling the generator 
This 425 2burner Coleman stove has remained relatively unchanged in more than 50 years This stove is simple mechanically bombproof and offers features unmatched by todays assortment of higherpriced more convenient stoves For example the 425 may be found nearly everywhere and shares rarely needed replacement parts across the product line Tanks valves and generators are nearly interchangeable The stove is easy to clean spacious and offers two burners the main with a higher output and a secondary controlled by a simple turn key on the lefthand side of the stove case for simmering This means that Iron Chefwannabes can easily cook multiple entrees or multicourse meals on the camp table The case offers a builtin windscreen The tank is suspended by two tabs although you can pin the tank if desired The pump uses the ubiquitous Coleman pump assembly although more recently this assembly uses a plastic washer This stove will last a lifetime and you will not be disappointed It is one of the most classic stove designs in history 
My 2 burner Coleman Dual Fuel stove is one that my father bought when I was a kid to take camping in our pop up I remember many meals prepared on it back then I stopped camping for about 25 years and just recently decided to start camping again with my family I knew the Coleman would have to come with us So I got my Dads old Coleman stove and put a little Coleman fuel in it pumped it up and it still runs like a champ This is one piece of camping equipment that is nearly indestructible if you take any care of it at all I know this stove sat unused for at least 20 years and probably a good bit longer As stated by others not backpacking equipment but perfect for rving and car camping This is one of the few products made by any company that lives up to its reputation and actually exceeds it by a fair margin You really cant go wrong with this little stove Easy to use easy to transport and it will outlast you most likely Its something that can be handed down to your kids or even grandkids someday

Love it Bright reliable light source Dual fuel makes it even better for flexibility Its Coleman  they have been doing the camping business for a LONG time and have it mostly figured out Parts are readily available at just about every store from the big box locations to the momnpop outdoors stores should you ever need to make repairs or just buy some replacement mantles Solid quality 
We had a couple of these years ago We are pretty serious about camping and I know a thing or two about Coleman liquid fueled lanterns so I wanted to share my experience with the Dual Fuel model Its a liquidfueled two sock mantle lantern It burns either gasoline regular unleaded or Colemans camp fuel a classified mixture probably mostly naphtha and some additives for storage life You have adjustable light outputs and runs on air pressure Its incredibly simple and there are few moving parts so its incredibly reliable You can also repair it if something breaks or wears out Its made almost entirely of steel with the exception of brass generator and pump parts and the brass fuel cap plastic fuel control knob thats been coated in enamel the chimney and top cap for long life and heat resistance The fuel tank is painted heavy gauge steel and the rest of the lantern globe holderbase heat shield valve shroud is stamped galvanized sheet steel It will last a long time if you take care of it Its simple how it works The pressurized fuel is squirted up the brass generator to a burner at the top The fuel is sprayed out of the generator and disperses in the burner The operation depends on high temperatures to work right so it has to warm up hence the mantles being close to the generator The heat vaporizes the fuel into a gas and it passes down the burner stalks and is ignited which burns very hot and makes the mantles glow If lighting for the first time you need to burnin the mantles Make sure theyre tied tightly to the burner stalks Doesnt matter how they are positioned Fill the fuel tank dont overfill it or youll get leaks and it could catch fire when you light it cap it Unscrew the pump 2 turns and pump it up 3050 times Make sure your thumb covers the vent hole on the pump knob Dont over pump it When it gets stiff stop If youre burning in the mantles light them on fire I use a barbecue lighter to reach through the hole on the globe support and light each mantle Let them burn until they are mostly white ash and while they are burning open the fuel valve until you get fire Dont turn it up high keep it on low until the mantles are completely burned and are white Youll get fire coming out of the burners and thats normal until the generator gets hot and vaporizes the fuel It takes about a minute for it to reach operating temperature and the mantles start glowing on their own and the fire stops You might have to pump it some more while its lighting for more pressure Thats it It can be kind of intimidating at first with the fire coming out but thats normal and will go away Dont worry it wont explode Just dont turn the fuel valve on high while its doing that or you could get big fire Once youve done it a couple times you get used to it Its really bright on full blast Will light up a campsite no problem Brighter than an LED lantern and the fuel tank will last you about 810 hours on full power I have run it two evenings and nights before and only used 34 of the fuel so it lasts quite a while It can burn either regular unleaded gasoline or Colemans own fuel I prefer gasoline because its cheaper about 350 a gallon opposed to almost 9 for the other stuff I noticed it doesnt run as long or get as bright on gasoline but the difference is made up for in the cost savings Its very durable The only real issue I had was from taking them razor clamming and getting ocean water on them which rusted the exposed metal and made a real mess of the lantern It still worked fine though after some cleaning If you properly maintain it it will last for decades The only consumable parts are the mantles and possibly the rubber seal in the air pump piston which can dry rot over time if not kept oiled use a medium oil you want something viscous like just regular general purpose oil I use Hoppes oil Everything else lasts a long time the life of the lantern If something does go bad you can order a new part from Coleman I rebuilt another one of these not dual fuel with offshelf parts and some parts I had to order from Coleman it works great Its also cheap to fix On the downside not really a fault of the lantern is that you cant take it in a tent with you like an LED lamp It makes carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide on gasoline plus it gets real hot It makes a great hand warmer though Its also fragile due to the glass globe and mantles so you have to be a little careful transporting it The plastic cover is nice but make sure the locking tabs are pressed into the base to keep it from falling out Plus it can hold mantles in the space under the fuel tank Pros Very bright Lasts forever Uses cheap unleaded gas Easy to maintain Long run time Cons Can be intimidating the first time you use it Not cheap If I had a choice between an LED lamp and this Id probably choose both LED for in my tent and the gas for outside Its not cheap and is designed for outdoor use only but you cant fault it It is super bright will last for thousands of hours and is cheap to run Gets my high recommendation 
I love this lamp I went through a few mantels at first but now the mantle seems to be lasting forever And Ive been using gasoline onlyive burned almost 2 gal by now thats a lot of burn time I burn this lamp all night long when Im in bear country It will last all night long if you fill it full and not at full blast I only put it on full blast if Im setting up tent at night its so bright it hurts your eyes at full blast 
ok

12 stars The stakes before I used them I thought they were great The whole setup is quite inexpensive and these are some nice looking heavy duty stakes The flimsy stakes that come with most tents are only acceptable in perfect weather and having this kit in my trunk with these stakes gave me peace of mind Then last weekend it was very windy when I put up my tent and I didnt think the stock stakes would hold so I used these They did their job well they held the tent and stayed sturdy despite some pretty nasty windsthen I tried to break camp on Sunday Well these are 10 nail style stakes They hold well You need some real leverage to get them out The nail head offers nothing The plastic at the top broke At that point any hope of ever getting these out of the ground were gone I had to work my tent loops up and over the stakes and leave the stakes in the ground as there was no way I was ever getting them out Id suggest holding on to these for nothing but emergency use and buy a set of sturdy aluminum stakes with a metal loop at the top like the Kelty No Bendium stakes or with the nylon pull strings like the Coleman Heavy Duty stakes or MSR Ground Hogs The stakes are only 2 stars 2 and not 1 since they do work well as heavy duty stakes in a pinch but especially in hard ground or heavy roots youll never be able to recover them The stake puller is OK It seems like it is a bit flimsy When using the cheaper pegs that come with my tents it does a fine job pulling them up When using longer pegs like the aforementioned stakes that come with this set it did do some bending It is still useable but I think I will be looking for something heavier duty 3 stars So overall it is an OK set It probably serves best to keep it in your trunk at all times in case you need it and forgot something when packing for camping Price is good so if you are camping and forgot something and need something now and this is all the stores have youll be fine with it to fill in for your regular gear All the items seem a little flimsy for longterm use Good in a pinch not so good for your goto gear

We own both this Coleman Road Trip Beach Shade and the SportsBrella XL We brought both down to the Oregon coast last weekend and tried them both in the beach environment we normally use them for baseball games   Pros  The Coleman provides better sun protection then the SportsBrella XL as it has a greater depth an no pole in the middle More people can fit under it comfortably  The Coleman packs up nice and tight and can fit anywhere the SportsBrellaXL would not have fit in our car minivan was fine going through the middle seats Cons  The Coleman was absolute hell to get setup with moderate winds coming off the Pacific and its flexible frame made it constantly move and bend in the wind In contrast the SportsBrellaXL was very easy to setup  Likewise the Coleman was hell to tear down and packup with the wind where as the SportsBrella was one button press  I originally though the floor of the Coleman would be a benefit but honestly with small kids within 30 minutes the whole inside was filled with sand

Lets face it  when camping there are two categories of gear necessities and other stuff that may be helpful This package from Coleman consisting of 1 a small broom and dustpan 2 four aluminum stakes 3 a rubberheaded mallet and 4 a stake remover definitely falls in the second category 1 Broom and dustpan  small plastic and green this just might get the most use out of anything in the package Not much to say here  it does its job Save the plastic wrapper this comes in because its hard to get the broom back into the mesh bag without it 2 Four aluminum stakes  these are actually pretty good The stakes are much longer and sturdier than the ones that came with my tent They are essentially giant nails with a green plastic head attached for the line to tie onto I would worry about cracking the heads if they got too cold 3 Rubberheaded mallet  much more substantial than you might think good heft to this and it will do its job and any others that might call for a similar tool A bit heavy if anything 4 Stake remover  Cheap bends out of shape All of this comes packed in a little mesh bag The bag is not really big enough for all of this stuff nor is it really sturdy enough to put up with any amount of abuse and the stakes punch right through the bottom Bottom line  you can camp a thousand times without having this set and you would never miss it but its always nice to have extra stakes and a way to clean your tent floor For the price its not a bad set to have 
The rubber mallet and stakes are good They both worked more than adequately even in the rocky ground where first used Remainder of the items are really not worth the price Broompan are really small and cheap plastic Stake puller may be OK in softer ground but easily bent the first time it was used pulling stakes Should say though that stakes were driven in pretty rocky ground and rather hard to pull so puller may work OK in softer ground Overall item is probably overpriced for what you get

Works very well No leaks Being able to shut off the water at the business end of the hose is a useful feature

I bought these from either Walmart or Kmart separately Dishes They are actually pretty decent but I have not been careful with them and now they are chipping I suggest getting a bag for them  or one of those fabric coolers on wheels which is what I opted for The best way to care for them besides not throwing them around or dropping them is to make sure they are packed tightly and separate each piece with paper towel The edges are a bit sharp but nothing Ive cut myself on Like any dishware they scratch and chip if you are not careful This dishware is strong and sturdy but once scratchedchipped beware of rust Also hot foods will heat the dishes and can burn you Common sense but worth mentioning Silverware These are ok and worth having if youre sick of wasting money and plastic on throwaway utensils Heres what I think is important when cleaning be aware of any food stuck on the inside of the fork tines and the knife serrations Also clean the area where the metal meets the handle I dont have a problem but I can see how food could build up there if you are not careful Again common sense The knives are actually very useful  I can cut steak with them That also means they can scratch the dishes I threw the carrying case into the washer and dryer and it might have tried to shrink a little but everything still fits inside perfectly All said and done I still think these are worth buying  if you take care of them
